commit_message:
VMware: Added doc for VMware VMDK cinder driver

Added document describing configuration of the driver and supported operations
when using it for cinder volume management.

Updated volume section in doc/common/section_vmware.xml.

Change-Id: I1181f8c834c916ef241a5abdeb48ab85b778d8e7
Implements: blueprint vmware-vmdk-cinder-driver
(cherry picked from commit 280d84e86602fd5ee6bfb50c31c3e61987e461f1)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/06/54506/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <para>The VMware driver supports attaching volumes from the OpenStack Block Storage service. 'iscsi' volume driver provides limited support and can be used only for attachments. VMware VMDK driver of OpenStack Block Storage can be used for managing volumes based out of vSphere datastores.</para>
deleted_lines: <para>The VMware driver has limited support for attaching Volumes from the OpenStack Block Storage service, supporting attachments only if the volume driver type is 'iscsi'. There is no support for volumes based on vCenter Datastores in this release.</para>

commit_message:
Adding support for multiple hypervisor versions

This is to prevent instances with newer tools from being provisioned
on older hypervisors.
Added comparison of hypervisor version from the compute-node and image
metadata in the image properties filter.
In host scheduler image_prop_filter, the 'hypervisor_version_requires'
image properties, if available, is compared to the host_state's
hypervisor_version, if available.
hypervisor_version_requires should be added on the image as metadata and
should have a operator and version value.
Examples : ">=6.0", ">6.0, <6.2", ""!=6.1"

Partially Implements blueprint xen-support-for-hypervisor-versions
Cell scheduler changes coming up in another commit.
DocImpact

Change-Id: I6fbf232adf9ac78ebb8ac2985739f163f4517d14
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/73/36073/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: sv = dct.get("software-version", "") osv = {} if sv: for svln in sv.split("; "): svk, svv = strip_kv(svln) osv[svk] = svv out["host_product_version"] = osv["product_version"]
deleted_lines: # sv = dct.get("software-version", "") # out["host_software-version"] = osv = {} # if sv: # for svln in sv.split("; "): # svk, svv = strip_kv(svln) # osv[svk] = svv

commit_message:
Replace tests.base part6

It is the sixth step to replace using ceilometer.tests.base with
openstack.common.test.
In this patch is changed for using
openstack.common.test and added needed fixtures in
test classes.
Added in ceilometer.tests.db code from ceilomete.tests.base
because ceilometer.tests.base will not be used in the future.

Change-Id: I3cacca4eff19eae8874decd892ab1225f95cfee9

commit_message:
baremetal: Add missing method to volume driver

Added get_hypervisor_version(), which is called by underlying
LibvirtVolumeDrivers. Also added tests roughly checking if the
underlying drivers can be loaded and be called without error.

Partial-Bug: #1208707
Change-Id: Ida6b6800d1ef518c6e76d6b2ab4ac2f795a744ca

added_lines: from nova.virt import fake from nova.virt.libvirt import volume as libvirt_volume class BareMetalLibVirtVolumeDriverTestCase(test.TestCase): def setUp(self): super(BareMetalLibVirtVolumeDriverTestCase, self).setUp() self.flags(libvirt_volume_drivers=[ 'fake=nova.virt.libvirt.volume.LibvirtFakeVolumeDriver', 'fake2=nova.virt.libvirt.volume.LibvirtFakeVolumeDriver', ]) self.driver = volume_driver.LibvirtVolumeDriver(fake.FakeVirtAPI()) self.disk_info = { 'dev': 'vdc', 'bus': 'baremetal', 'type': 'baremetal', } self.connection_info = {'driver_volume_type': 'fake'} def test_init_loads_libvirt_volume_drivers(self): self.assertEqual(type(self.driver.volume_drivers['fake']), libvirt_volume.LibvirtFakeVolumeDriver) self.assertEqual(type(self.driver.volume_drivers['fake2']), libvirt_volume.LibvirtFakeVolumeDriver) self.assertEqual(len(self.driver.volume_drivers), 2) def test_fake_connect_volume(self): """Check connect_volume returns without exceptions.""" self.driver._volume_driver_method('connect_volume', self.connection_info, self.disk_info)

The create-nodes script didn't cope well with libvirt storage pool
named "default" being in non-standard location. It created the images

commit_message:
Respect storage pool path in create-nodes script

The create-nodes script didn't cope well with libvirt storage pool
named "default" being in non-standard location. It created the images
in correct location, but passed incorrect image path into configure-vm
script, because the image path was hard coded.

Now the script queries for correct location of the image using virsh.

Change-Id: Ia049a7496d4df0ae9f0c606a3d6279b9f94c56fc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-incubator refs/changes/85/54385/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: configure-vm --bootdev network --name baremetal_$idx --image /var/lib/libvirt/images/baremetal-$idx.qcow2 --arch $ARCH --cpus $CPU --memory $MEM >&2 sudo chattr +C /var/lib/libvirt/images/baremetal-$idx.qcow2 || true

commit_message:
Allow Neutron to schedule networks lazily

When a new network is created, Neutron won't schedule it
to one of the active DHCP agents until the first port on
this network is allocated.

This means that we should not bother to schedule the created
network manually and can just rely on Neutron for doing this
(actually, we've already been relying on Neutron for Seed VM,
since we switched to using of neutron-dhcp-agent).

Related-Bug: #1231366

Change-Id: I413407effe93312f2b5dd69d673590043becca33
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-incubator refs/changes/21/54121/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: # See bug 1231366 - this may become part of setup-neutron if that is # determined to be not a bug. wait_for 30 10 neutron agent-list \| grep DHCP UNDERCLOUD_DHCP_AGENT_UUID=$(neutron agent-list | awk '/DHCP/ { print $2 }') # NOTE(rpodolyaka): by the time we've got here the network might have already # been scheduled, so the next command can possibly fail with # 'network has already been hosted' error. That would mean # we are done here and can continue. neutron dhcp-agent-network-add $UNDERCLOUD_DHCP_AGENT_UUID ctlplane || true

commit_message:
VMware: Using auto-gen table in cinder driver doc

Currently, the configuration options for VMware VMDK drivers are
hard-coded in the reference source xml (doc/config-reference/
block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.xml). This change replaces
the hard-coded configuration options with a reference to auto-generated
config options file at doc/common/tables/cinder-vmware.xml.

Closes-Bug: #1245784
backport: havana
Change-Id: I4efb85ef0d1e082eac77daa1722b6bab831ae67d

commit_message:
Reworks HTTP Patch support and adds validation for Node

Adds in reference implementation for:

Initial work for adding validation to WSME complex
types (this adds an initial layer of validation when
the data first enters the API)

Adding support for blacklisting of attributes.

Also, reworks much of the common HTTP Patch code into
resuable methods accessible in the WSME complex types.
Change-Id: I030b08a719c962f419f45e35e9d7a72e1eb0042f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/82/49582/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def blacklist(self): """Specifies a list of attributes that are not directly modifiable via the API""" #TODO(mtaylor):Add i18n support for messages state_message = 'Changing states is not allowed here; You must use the\ nodes/%s/state interface' % self.uuid # Setting the value to None forces use of default message return {'id': None, 'updated_at': None, 'created_at': None, 'power_state': state_message, 'target_power_state': state_message, 'provision_state': state_message, 'target_provision_state': state_message} @staticmethod def defaults(): return objects.Node.get_defaults() def validate_resource(self, new_obj): """Adds custom validation to node""" errors = [] try: super(Node, self).validate_resource(new_obj) except wsme.exc.ClientSideError as e: errors = [e.message] if any(getattr(self, tgt) for tgt in ["target_power_state", "target_provision_state"]): errors.append("Can not update node %s because a state change is \ already in progress." % self.uuid) if errors: raise wsme.exc.ClientSideError(", ".join(errors)) def _get_node(self, uuid): """Retrieve information about the given node.""" rpc_node = objects.Node.get_by_uuid(pecan.request.context, uuid) return Node.convert_with_links(rpc_node) return self._get_node(uuid) if self._from_chassis: raise exception.OperationNotPermitted node = self._get_node(uuid) diff = node.patch(patch) diff) return Node.convert_with_links(node) #TODO(mtaylor) Move generic error handling to a hook called on error
deleted_lines: """Retrieve information about the given node.""" rpc_node = objects.Node.get_by_uuid(pecan.request.context, uuid) return Node.convert_with_links(rpc_node) if self._from_chassis: raise exception.OperationNotPermitted node = objects.Node.get_by_uuid(pecan.request.context, uuid) node_dict = node.as_dict() utils.validate_patch(patch) patch_obj = jsonpatch.JsonPatch(patch) # Prevent states from being updated state_rel_path = ['/power_state', '/target_power_state', '/provision_state', '/target_provision_state'] if any(p['path'] in state_rel_path for p in patch_obj): raise wsme.exc.ClientSideError(_("Changing states is not allowed " "here; You must use the " "nodes/%s/state interface.") % uuid) # Prevent node from being updated when there's a state # change in progress if any(node.get(tgt) for tgt in ["target_power_state", "target_provision_state"]): raise wsme.exc.ClientSideError(_("Can not update node %s because " "a state change is already in " "progress.") % uuid) try: patched_node = jsonpatch.apply_patch(node_dict, patch_obj) except jsonpatch.JsonPatchException as e: LOG.exception(e) raise wsme.exc.ClientSideError(_("Patching Error: %s") % e) self. _convert_chassis_uuid_to_id(patched_node) defaults = objects.Node.get_defaults() for key in defaults: # Internal values that shouldn't be part of the patch if key in ['id', 'updated_at', 'created_at']: continue # In case of a remove operation, add the missing fields back # to the document with their default value if key in node_dict and key not in patched_node: patched_node[key] = defaults[key] # Update only the fields that have changed if node[key] != patched_node[key]: node[key] = patched_node[key] node) response.obj = node # TODO(deva): return the response object instead of raising # after wsme 0.5b3 is released if response.status_code not in [200, 202]: raise wsme.exc.ClientSideError(_( "Error updating node %s") % uuid) return Node.convert_with_links(response.obj)

Install Guide: Fix service names for Ubuntu and openSUSE

For Ubuntu:
openvswitch->openvswitch-switch
neutron-openvswitch-agent->neutron-plugin-openvswitch-agent
For openSUSE:
neutron-openvswitch-agent->openstack-neutron-openvswitch-agent

backport: havana
Closes-Bug: 1246021
(cherry picked from commit 7ec6ae8c616e47559d4a062b3f0a3fc98ac824fa)

Install Guide: Fix nova.conf for nova-network

Setup nova.conf properly
Start libvirtd (openSUSE/SLES)

improve perfomance of nailgun component

builtin json serialization is slow
use ujson library for parts where we have perfomance issues

Rename heat_watch_server_url to watch_server_url

The other *_server_url parameters are not prefixed with heat_ and this
is already in the heat namespace.

commit_message:
Rename heat_watch_server_url to watch_server_url

The Readme for heat-engine says it should be watch_server_url and
{{heat.watch_server_url}} is what is being used in heat.conf.

Change-Id: Ibcfec34c85901592c47eaf911aeb2eaa8049dfb7

commit_message:
Support extention floating-ip-bulk-list when use neutron

When use neutron, the extension floating-ip-bulk-list still use
nova db as query source, the result always return [].

    * Add get_floating_ips_all() for floating-ip-bulk-list
    * Add get_floating_ips_all_by_host() for option '--host'
    * Add unit test

Closes-Bug #1230089

Change-Id: Ie933328c98457828c54ad7c6bfc1d80a353a9865
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/79/48579/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova import network"""The Floating IPs API controller for the OpenStack API.""" def __init__(self): self.network_api = network.API() super(FloatingIPBulkController, self).__init__() floating_ips = self.network_api.get_floating_ips_all(context) else: floating_ips = self.network_api.get_floating_ips_by_host( context, host) instance_uuid = floating_ip['instance']['uuid']
deleted_lines: floating_ips = db.floating_ip_get_all(context) else: floating_ips = db.floating_ip_get_all_by_host(context, host) fixed_ip = db.fixed_ip_get(context, floating_ip['fixed_ip_id']) instance_uuid = fixed_ip['instance_uuid'] 'interface': floating_ip['interface'],

commit_message:
Add security groups updating test for ports

Add new function test_update_port_with_security_groups() for testing
update ports with new created valid security groups.
Add new function test_update_port_with_nonexistent_security_groups()
for negative tests.

Change-Id: Iba96704d132b6f4461b041216817ff718b59db9e

deleted_lines: new_port = "New_Port"

commit_message:
Grant apache permissions on Ubuntu 13.10

Just like https://bugs.launchpad.net/devstack/+bug/1167066 does:

  Starting with ubuntu 13.10 the horizon.conf has
    <Directory />
        AllowOverride none
        Require all denied
    </Directory>
  which requires you to explicitly permit access to web content
  directories in other <Directory> blocks

Fixes: Bug #1241574

commit_message:
keystone : Add coverage of v2 client trust scoping

Adds coverage of re-scoping a v2 client to a trust, as described in
bug #1231483.  the tests will need to be skipped until the patch from
that bug gets merged into keystoneclient.

blueprint: keystoneclient-api
Change-Id: I41afcdcafe89aa35ff03fbc373ab83c495adce38
Partial-Bug: #1231483
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/60/51560/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from keystoneclient.v2_0 import client as kc_v2from tempest.test import skip_because # TODO(shardy): we need the demo user to have a demo role, which we can # TODO(shardy): The get_id stuff in keystoneclient doesn't seem to # work for users created via the v2 API (or maybe at all), need to # investigate, probably a keystoneclient bug, have to use ID's atm. @skip_because(bug='1231483') def test_trust_auth_v2client_impersonate(self): """ It is also possible to get a trust-scoped token from the v2 tokens API So check we can do this via keystoneclient, requires bug #1231483 patch """ # Create a trust via the v3 API self._create_trust() # Then consume it via the v2 tokens API, by re-scoping the token via # authenticate() trust_client = kc_v2.Client( username=self.trustee_username, password=self.trustee_password, tenant_name=self.trustee_tenant_name, auth_url=self.config.identity.uri) ret = trust_client.authenticate( trust_id=self.trust_id, tenant_id=self.trustor_tenant_id) self.assertTrue(ret) self.assertTrue(trust_client.auth_ref.trust_scoped) self.assertEqual(self.trust_id, trust_client.auth_ref.trust_id) # TODO(shardy) this assert needs bug #1239303 fixed or it fails self.assertEqual(self.trustor_user_id, trust_client.auth_ref.user_id) @skip_because(bug='1231483') def test_trust_auth_v2client_noimpersonate(self): """ It is also possible to get a trust-scoped token from the v2 tokens API So check we can do this via keystoneclient, requires bug #1231483 patch """ # Create a trust via the v3 API self._create_trust(impersonation=False) # Then consume it via the v2 tokens API, by re-scoping the token via # authenticate() trust_client = kc_v2.Client( username=self.trustee_username, password=self.trustee_password, tenant_name=self.trustee_tenant_name, auth_url=self.config.identity.uri) ret = trust_client.authenticate( trust_id=self.trust_id, tenant_id=self.trustor_tenant_id) self.assertTrue(ret) self.assertTrue(trust_client.auth_ref.trust_scoped) self.assertEqual(self.trust_id, trust_client.auth_ref.trust_id) self.assertEqual(self.trustee_user_id, trust_client.auth_ref.user_id)

commit_message:
Add initial keystoneclient trusts tests

Adds initial tests which excercise the keystoneclient v3 trusts API
not a comprehensive test, but provides basic smoke-test coverage

blueprint: keystoneclient-api
Change-Id: Icb9e1dfc79bb4a12a8bf9e3b67949c311e98feee
Partial-Bug: #1231483
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/59/51559/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4 # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from keystoneclient.v3 import client as kc_v3 from tempest.client_lib.keystone.test_v3_auth import ClientV3AuthTest from tempest.common import log as logging from tempest import exceptions from tempest.scenario import manager LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class TestClientV3Auth(ClientV3AuthTest): """ Test to exercise the trust related intefaces of keystoneclient. """ def setUp(self): super(TestClientV3Auth, self).setUp() self.trustor_username = self.config.identity.username self.trustor_password = self.config.identity.password self.trustor_tenant_name = self.config.identity.tenant_name self.trustee_username = self.config.identity.alt_username self.trustee_password = self.config.identity.alt_password self.trustee_tenant_name = self.config.identity.alt_tenant_name # FIXME: we need the demo user to have a demo role, which we can # delegate to the alt_demo user, should we create that here, or # should it be added to the default config? self.delegated_roles = ['demo'] self.trust_id = None self.addCleanup(self._cleanup_trust) def _cleanup_trust(self): """ Cleanup trust if the test created one. """ client = self._get_identity_client_v3() if self.trust_id: trustor_client = self._get_identity_client_v3( username=self.trustor_username, password=self.trustor_password, tenant_name=self.trustor_tenant_name, endpoint=self.auth_url) trustor_client.authenticate() trustor_client.trusts.delete(self.trust_id) def _create_trust(self, impersonation=True): """ Create a trust set the id in self.trust_id. """ # Create a client for the trustor user # We have to specify endpoint here, or we end up trying to # POST /v2.0/OS-TRUST/trusts instead of using the v3 url # This also means we need an explicit authenticate() to get # a token.. trustor_client = self._get_identity_client_v3( username=self.trustor_username, password=self.trustor_password, tenant_name=self.trustor_tenant_name, endpoint=self.auth_url) trustor_client.authenticate() self.assertIsNotNone(trustor_client.auth_token) # Get the trustor user and tenant ID self.trustor_user_id = trustor_client.auth_ref.user_id self.trustor_tenant_id = trustor_client.auth_ref.tenant_id # Create a client for the trustee trustee_client = self._get_identity_client_v3( username=self.trustee_username, password=self.trustee_password, tenant_name=self.trustee_tenant_name) self.assertIsNotNone(trustee_client.auth_token) # Get the trustee user ID self.trustee_user_id = trustee_client.auth_ref.user_id trust = trustor_client.trusts.create( trustor_user=self.trustor_user_id, trustee_user=self.trustee_user_id, project=self.trustor_tenant_id, impersonation=impersonation, role_names=self.delegated_roles) self.assertIsNotNone(trust.id) self.trust_id = trust.id def test_trust_auth_impersonate(self): """ Test creating a v3 client scoped with a trust. """ self._create_trust() # Now create a client consuming the trust trust_client = self._get_identity_client_v3( username=self.trustee_username, password=self.trustee_password, tenant_name=self.trustee_tenant_name, trust_id=self.trust_id) self.assertIsNotNone(trust_client.auth_token) self.assertTrue(trust_client.auth_ref.trust_scoped) self.assertEqual(self.trust_id, trust_client.auth_ref.trust_id) self.assertEqual(self.trustor_user_id, trust_client.auth_ref.user_id) def test_trust_auth_noimpersonate(self): """ Test creating a v3 client scoped with a trust. """ self._create_trust(impersonation=False) # Now create a client consuming the trust trust_client = self._get_identity_client_v3( username=self.trustee_username, password=self.trustee_password, tenant_name=self.trustee_tenant_name, trust_id=self.trust_id) self.assertIsNotNone(trust_client.auth_token) self.assertTrue(trust_client.auth_ref.trust_scoped) self.assertEqual(self.trust_id, trust_client.auth_ref.trust_id) self.assertEqual(self.trustee_user_id, trust_client.auth_ref.user_id)

commit_message:
Add tests for SQLAlchemy Util's `modify_indexes`

In preparation for a bug fix to `modify_indexes`, this patch introduces
testing around the existing functionality.

Additional cleanups:

* Added support for SQLite (no indication why this was originally skipped and
  tests pass)
* Fixed Postgres case (it failed with duplicate column errors)
* Added `get_indexes` helper
* Added `get_foreign_keys` helper

Change-Id: I38dc4e260d6aea446438202f1f5146ad3aa1b6fc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/77/53177/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: real_indexes = utils.get_indexes(engine, table_name) f_keys = utils.get_foreign_keys(engine, table_name) def test_get_indexes(self): table_name = 'abc' for engine in self.engines.itervalues(): meta = MetaData() meta.bind = engine table = Table(table_name, meta, Column('id', String(255), primary_key=True), Column('foo', String(255)), Index('ix_abc_foo', 'foo') ) table.create() real_indexes = utils.get_indexes(engine, table_name) self.assertEqual(['ix_abc_foo'], [i['name'] for i in real_indexes]) def test_get_foreign_keys(self): for engine in self.engines.itervalues(): meta = MetaData() meta.bind = engine parent_table = Table('table0', meta, Column('id', Integer, primary_key=True), Column('foo', Integer), mysql_engine='InnoDB') parent_table.create() table_name = 'table1' table = Table(table_name, meta, Column('id', Integer, primary_key=True), Column('baz', Integer), Column('bar', Integer, ForeignKey("table0.id")), mysql_engine='InnoDB') table.create() fks = utils.get_foreign_keys(engine, table_name) self.assertEqual(1, len(fks)) self.assertEqual(['bar'], fks[0]['constrained_columns']) class ModifyIndexesTests(test_migrations.BaseMigrationTestCase): def test_unsupported_engine(self): class FakeEngine(object): pass engine = FakeEngine() engine.name = 'unknown' self.assertRaises( ValueError, utils.modify_indexes, engine, {}, upgrade=True) def test_upgrade_downgrade(self): table_name = 'abc' for engine in self.engines.itervalues(): meta = MetaData() meta.bind = engine table = Table(table_name, meta, Column('id', String(255), primary_key=True), Column('name', String(255)), Column('deleted', Boolean), Index('ix_abc_name', 'name') ) table.create() real_indexes = utils.get_indexes(engine, table_name) self.assertEqual([['name']], [i['column_names'] for i in real_indexes]) modify_data = {table_name: [('ix_abc_name', ['name'], ['name', 'deleted'])]} # Upgrade utils.modify_indexes(engine, modify_data, upgrade=True) real_indexes = utils.get_indexes(engine, table_name) self.assertEqual([['name', 'deleted']], [i['column_names'] for i in real_indexes]) # Downgrade utils.modify_indexes(engine, modify_data, upgrade=False) real_indexes = utils.get_indexes(engine, table_name) self.assertEqual([['name']], [i['column_names'] for i in real_indexes])
deleted_lines: from sqlalchemy.engine import reflection insp = reflection.Inspector.from_engine(engine) real_indexes = insp.get_indexes(table_name) insp = reflection.Inspector.from_engine(engine) f_keys = insp.get_foreign_keys(table_name)

commit_message:
Handle unrecognized CLI response for Huawei driver

To avoid the risk of an infinite loop when T driver reading CLI result,
this patch adds a determination of unrecognized CLI response.

Change-Id: I5438b9a2d0f395f914d0aa4f97b5819e34ec31b4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/30/52830/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: start_time = time.time() # Handle unrecognized CLI response. else: cur_time = time.time() if get_time_interval(start_time, cur_time) > timeout: msg = _('Unrecognized CLI response. Be forced to' 'exit after %s s.') % timeout LOG.error(msg) raise exception.CinderException(msg)def get_time_interval(start_time, end_time): """Get the time interval. This func is to easy unit test. """ return end_time - start_time

commit_message:
Don't attempt to zuulify the old tree

In the event that nothing else works, this change can be merged
to prevent us from attempting to zuulify the old tree at all. This
is known to work if the rest of the zuul changes don't.

Change-Id: Idffb05d4438fdf45eafc1a8e1b9e371b210e60d9

added_lines: From 7b59f9f2c54d4b1c5440b5fb8777029412bd95d5 Mon Sep 17 00:00:00 2001 From: Serg Melikyan <smelikyan@mirantis.com> Date: Wed, 30 Oct 2013 08:21:44 +0400 Subject: [PATCH] Added support for Allow-Address-Pairs feature Added support for feature called Allow-Address-Pairs introduced in Ie73b3886c5be8e1fc4ade86a0cfb854267f345ac Refer to blueprint: allowed-address-pairs Change-Id: I75ba642a63c82f00f4d542512a1dbdf5755e9318 --- heat/engine/resources/quantum/port.py | 46 ++++++++++++++++++++------------- 1 file changed, 28 insertions(+), 18 deletions(-) diff --git a/heat/engine/resources/quantum/port.py b/heat/engine/resources/quantum/port.py index c09a072..467e8ff 100644 --- a/heat/engine/resources/quantum/port.py +++ b/heat/engine/resources/quantum/port.py @@ -21,24 +21,29 @@ logger = logging.getLogger(__name__) class Port(quantum.QuantumResource): - - fixed_ip_schema = {'subnet_id': {'Type': 'String', - 'Required': True}, - 'ip_address': {'Type': 'String'}} - - properties_schema = {'network_id': {'Type': 'String', - 'Required': True}, - 'name': {'Type': 'String'}, - 'value_specs': {'Type': 'Map', - 'Default': {}}, - 'admin_state_up': {'Default': True, - 'Type': 'Boolean'}, - 'fixed_ips': {'Type': 'List', - 'Schema': {'Type': 'Map', - 'Schema': fixed_ip_schema}}, - 'mac_address': {'Type': 'String'}, - 'device_id': {'Type': 'String'}, - 'security_groups': {'Type': 'List'}} + properties_schema = { + 'network_id': {'Type': 'String', 'Required': True}, + 'name': {'Type': 'String'}, + 'value_specs': {'Type': 'Map', 'Default': {}}, + 'admin_state_up': {'Default': True, 'Type': 'Boolean'}, + 'fixed_ips': { + 'Type': 'List', + 'Schema': {'Type': 'Map', 'Schema': { + 'subnet_id': {'Type': 'String', 'Required': True}, + 'ip_address': {'Type': 'String'} + }} + }, + 'mac_address': {'Type': 'String'}, + 'device_id': {'Type': 'String'}, + 'security_groups': {'Type': 'List'}, + 'allowed_address_pairs': { + 'Type': 'List', + 'Schema': {'Type': 'Map', 'Schema': { + 'mac_address': {'Type': 'String'}, + 'ip_address': {'Type': 'String', 'Required': True} + }} + } + } def __init__(self, name, json_snippet, stack): super(Port, self).__init__(name, json_snippet, stack) @@ -47,6 +52,11 @@ class Port(quantum.QuantumResource): props = self.prepare_properties( self.properties, self.physical_resource_name()) + + for pair in props.get('allowed_address_pairs', []): + if 'mac_address' in pair and pair['mac_address'] is None: + del pair['mac_address'] + port = self.quantum().create_port({'port': props})['port'] self.resource_id_set(port['id']) -- 1.7.9.5

commit_message:
Ensure apt-get installs do not prompt user input

Set DEBIAN_FRONTEND to noninteractive and add dpkg options to ensure
apt-get installs do not prompt for input and cause the stack-create to
fail.

Closes-Bug: #1245899

Change-Id: I294783fb565b854143bc8a5d15834d8d88ad1a70
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/90/54190/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: export DEBIAN_FRONTEND=noninteractive yes '' | apt-get install -y -o Dpkg::Options::="--force-confdef" -o \ Dpkg::Options::="--force-confold" cloud-init python-boto python-pip gcc \ python-devexport DEBIAN_FRONTEND=noninteractive yes '' | apt-get install -y -o Dpkg::Options::="--force-confdef" -o \ Dpkg::Options::="--force-confold" python-pip gcc python-dev
deleted_lines: apt-get install -y cloud-init python-boto python-pip gcc python-dev # - Debian 7: Not working (heat-cfntools patch submitted) # TODO(jason): Test with Debian 7 as soon as heat-cfntools patch # is in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/38822/apt-get install -y python-pip gcc python-dev

commit_message:
Register o-a-c managed files with use-ephemeral

We want to have elements directly making use of /mnt, but if they have
not yet migrated to this paradigm and an image is meant to use the
ephemeral drive for state, we can force the issue here.

Change-Id: I876f1f807f7b9888189ce9ce898a9d19091f85e1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-image-elements refs/changes/71/54471/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # If use-ephemeral has been included... if [ -x "$(which register-state-path)" ] ; then # Register any config files we will write not in /mnt as state files # -mindepth 2 ignores files in the template root, which should only # ever have directories anyway. find $TEMPLATE_ROOT ! -path "$TEMPLATE_ROOT/mnt/*" -mindepth 2 -type f -printf '/%P\0' | xargs -0 register-state-path --leave-symlink fi

Make register-state-path take multiple paths

This simplifies registering many files all at once.

added_lines: if [ -z "${1:-}" ]; then while [ -n "${1:-}" ] ; do STATE_PATH=$1 shift echo $STATE_PATH >> /var/lib/use-ephemeral/stateful-paths if [ -e "$STATE_PATH" -o -L "$STATE_PATH" ]; then backup_dir=/var/lib/use-ephemeral/$(dirname "$STATE_PATH") mkdir -p "$backup_dir" mv "$STATE_PATH" "$backup_dir" fi if [ -n "$LEAVE_SYMLINK" ]; then ln -s "/mnt/state/$STATE_PATH" "$STATE_PATH" fi done

commit_message:
Quarantine objects with busted metadata.

Before, if you encountered an object with corrupt or missing xattrs,
the object server would return a 500 on GET, and wouldn't quarantine
anything. Now the object server returns a 404 for that GET and the
corrupted file is quarantined, thus giving replication a chance to fix
it.

Change-Id: Ib1d7ab965391742c88fde3d83dc0b5afe85bada9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/39/53939/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: :returns: path to final file return target_path :raises DiskFileQuarantined: try: metadata = self._failsafe_read_metadata(ts_file, ts_file) except DiskFileQuarantined: # If the tombstone's corrupted, quarantine it and pretend it # wasn't there exc = DiskFileNotExist() else: # All well and good that we have found a tombstone file, but # we don't have a data file so we are just going to raise an # exception that we could not find the object, providing the # tombstone's timestamp. exc = DiskFileDeleted() exc.timestamp = metadata['X-Timestamp'] def _failsafe_read_metadata(self, source, quarantine_filename=None): # Takes source and filename separately so we can read from an open # file if we have one try: return read_metadata(source) except Exception as err: self._quarantine(quarantine_filename, "Exception reading metadata: %s" % err.message) datafile_metadata = self._failsafe_read_metadata(fp, data_file) if meta_file: self._metadata = self._failsafe_read_metadata(meta_file, meta_file)
deleted_lines: :raises DiskFileQuarantine: metadata = read_metadata(ts_file) # All well and good that we have found a tombstone file, but # we don't have a data file so we are just going to raise an # exception that we could not find the object, providing the # tombstone's timestamp. exc = DiskFileDeleted() exc.timestamp = metadata['X-Timestamp'] datafile_metadata = read_metadata(fp) if meta_file: self._metadata = read_metadata(meta_file)

The UUID for the server of interest to you.

commit_message:
Install Guide: Fix service names for Ubuntu and openSUSE

For Ubuntu:
openvswitch->openvswitch-switch
neutron-openvswitch-agent->neutron-plugin-openvswitch-agent
For openSUSE:
neutron-openvswitch-agent->openstack-neutron-openvswitch-agent

Change-Id: I8fa175b9a666a41818c1fc590fc34a9afbb91e32
backport: havana
Closes-Bug: 1246021

commit_message:
Only zuulify the tree if we are on the right branch

We need to be more careful in our selection of when we zuulify the
tree, because we now want to zuulify the "old" tree as well. But
only do that if the ZUUL_BRANCH matches the $branch we've told it
to setup the workspace for.

Change-Id: Ie0ef097949aa54cb720615df80ed3aba4c16cc30

commit_message:
Fix compatibility with latest puppetlabs-concat

concat::setup has been made a private class and can no longer be
included from modules outside concat itself.

concat::setup is already included by the concat define. Removing
its inclusion from puppet-swift classes shouldn't result in breakage
or loss of functionality.

Change-Id: I7566e09bd4e93aec719a495279cf92d8a898057e
Closes-bug: #1245936

deleted_lines: 'class { "concat::setup": } concat { "/etc/swift/dummy-server.conf": }'

commit_message:
Let us gate grenade forward

This sets up all the grenade variables both needed to cover Havana
and Icehouse runs, but also to provide a new DEVSTACK_GATE_GRENADE_FORWARD
that let's us do a forward upgrade on a stable branch.

Also, get completely explicit on all the branches, to ensure that we
know what directions we are headed in.

Update setup_workspace to take local variables of branch name to try
to make the code a little clearer, and move all the setup_workspace to
the same point in the script.

Co-Authored-By: Mauro S. M. Rodrigues <maurosr@linux.vnet.ibm.com>
Change-Id: Iffcbd127c20780c5de6a16c41d1f0fd9f0d4d470

commit_message:
Support port-list by node_id

The API service exposes "GET /nodes/UUID/ports",
but the client library doesn't implement this.
It is needed by the Nova driver.

Change-Id: Id3bb9d7d8c46102f4cb63a3ee65306cc07afb812
Closes-Bug: #1239028
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-ironicclient refs/changes/65/54065/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def list(self, fields): node_id = fields['node_id'] if node_id: return self._list('/v1/%s/ports/' % node_id, "ports") else: return self._list(self._path(), "ports")
deleted_lines: def list(self): return self._list(self._path(), "ports")

subject: Add DiskReader class to diskfile
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-08-27 23:37:08.000000000', 'files': ['test/unit/obj/test_auditor.py', 'swift/obj/server.py', 'swift/obj/auditor.py', 'test/unit/obj/test_server.py', 'test/unit/obj/test_diskfile.py', 'swift/common/exceptions.py', 'swift/obj/diskfile.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/3aa5117b48e5ad71e477f17d31da14016626945f', 'message': 'Add DiskReader class to diskfile

Move all .metadata access under DiskFile "open" in object-server

Raise DiskFileSizeInvalid when Content-Length does not match size

When get_obj_size raises a DiskFileSizeInvalid error it will automatically
quarantine the object.  This makes the quarantine method on the DiskReader
effectively private except when it's used explicitly by the auditor for
generic handling of unexpected DiskFileErrors.

Any attempt to iterate over an instance of DiskReader will ensure that the
obj_size has been validated against the Content-Length in the metadata.  The
object-server already did this, and it is now enforced in tests as well.

When closing a DiskReader, if the _obj_size has been set (either by an
explicit call to get_obj_size, or by iterating over the body) the close method
will always automatically attempt to verify and possibly quarantine the file.
Since a Content-Length mis-match would have been caught before iterating the
file this always automatic close verification will only effect the ETag
validation which is only performed when the entire body of the DiskReader is
consumed.  Setting a "verify_close" attribute on the reader instance will have
no effect.

Consolidate quarnatine call sites on DiskReader

Add keep_cache_size to DiskReader constructor so that the DiskReader class may
optionally keep smaller files in the page cache.
Remove keep_data_fp argument from DiskFile constructor

All access to the data_file fp for DiskFile is moved under the new "open"
method.  This reduces the surface area of the DiskFile abstraction and reduces
the exposure of the underlying implementation in the object-server.

Move all DiskFile artifact manipulation under DiskWriter

All write access to the underlying DiskFile artifacts has been moved to
DiskWriter.  DiskWriter will create .data, .meta, and .ts files as well as
delete them.  The public "unlinkold" DiskFile method has been moved to
DiskWriter and manages it's calling.

Expose public helper method "update_metadata" to replace put_metadata, and
re-factor "delete" to use DiskWriter directly and more efficiently.

New public "delete" method on DiskFile

Change-Id: I6b9ed674a557b229f8a754ad335f8dc9053f0218
'}]
commit_message:
Add DiskReader class to diskfile

Move all .metadata access under DiskFile "open" in object-server

Raise DiskFileSizeInvalid when Content-Length does not match size

When get_obj_size raises a DiskFileSizeInvalid error it will automatically
quarantine the object.  This makes the quarantine method on the DiskReader
effectively private except when it's used explicitly by the auditor for
generic handling of unexpected DiskFileErrors.

Any attempt to iterate over an instance of DiskReader will ensure that the
obj_size has been validated against the Content-Length in the metadata.  The
object-server already did this, and it is now enforced in tests as well.

When closing a DiskReader, if the _obj_size has been set (either by an
explicit call to get_obj_size, or by iterating over the body) the close method
will always automatically attempt to verify and possibly quarantine the file.
Since a Content-Length mis-match would have been caught before iterating the
file this always automatic close verification will only effect the ETag
validation which is only performed when the entire body of the DiskReader is
consumed.  Setting a "verify_close" attribute on the reader instance will have
no effect.

Consolidate quarnatine call sites on DiskReader

Add keep_cache_size to DiskReader constructor so that the DiskReader class may
optionally keep smaller files in the page cache.
Remove keep_data_fp argument from DiskFile constructor

All access to the data_file fp for DiskFile is moved under the new "open"
method.  This reduces the surface area of the DiskFile abstraction and reduces
the exposure of the underlying implementation in the object-server.

Move all DiskFile artifact manipulation under DiskWriter

All write access to the underlying DiskFile artifacts has been moved to
DiskWriter.  DiskWriter will create .data, .meta, and .ts files as well as
delete them.  The public "unlinkold" DiskFile method has been moved to
DiskWriter and manages it's calling.

Expose public helper method "update_metadata" to replace put_metadata, and
re-factor "delete" to use DiskWriter directly and more efficiently.

New public "delete" method on DiskFile

Change-Id: I6b9ed674a557b229f8a754ad335f8dc9053f0218

Serves as the context manager object for DiskFile's "create" method. :param device_path: path to device (e.g. /srv/node/sdb) :param datadir: path to destination hash :param name: name of the object (e.g. /a/c/o) :param size: optional size in bytes to fallocate :param bytes_per_sync: number of bytes between fdatasync calls :param threadpool: thread pool in which to do blocking operations def __init__(self, device_path, datadir, name, size=None, bytes_per_sync=(512 * 1024 * 1024), threadpool=None): self.tmpdir = join(device_path, 'tmp') self.datadir = datadir self.name = name self.size = size self.fd = None self.tmppath = None self.bytes_per_sync = bytes_per_sync self.threadpool = threadpool or ThreadPool(nthreads=0) def __enter__(self): """ Open handle to temporary path, creating directory if needed. If size was specified it will be fallocated here and raise if unavailable. :raises: DiskFileNoSpace """ if not exists(self.tmpdir): mkdirs(self.tmpdir) self.fd, self.tmppath = mkstemp(dir=self.tmpdir) if self.size is not None and self.size > 0: try: fallocate(self.fd, self.size) except OSError: raise DiskFileNoSpace() self._timestamp = None self._save_old_data = False return self def __exit__(self, t, v, tb): try: if self.fd: os.close(self.fd) except OSError: pass try: if self.tmppath: os.unlink(self.tmppath) except OSError: pass if not self._save_old_data: self.unlinkold() :raises: DiskWriterNotReady if called out of context if not self.fd: raise DiskWriterNotReady() if diff >= self.bytes_per_sync: def _put(self, metadata, extension='.data'): :raises: DiskWriterNotReady if called out of context if not self.fd: raise DiskWriterNotReady() self._timestamp = normalize_timestamp(metadata['X-Timestamp']) metadata['name'] = self.name invalidate_hash(dirname(self.datadir)) data_file = join(self.datadir, self._timestamp + extension) renamer(self.tmppath, data_file) self._data_file = data_file self._metadata = metadata def put(self, metadata): return self._put(metadata) def put_metadata(self, metadata): self._save_old_data = True return self._put(metadata, extension='.meta') def put_tombstone(self, req_timestamp): metadata = {'X-Timestamp': req_timestamp} return self._put(metadata, extension='.ts') def unlinkold(self): """ Remove any older versions of the object file. Any file that has an older timestamp than timestamp will be deleted. :param timestamp: timestamp to compare with each file """ if not self._timestamp: return def _unlinkold(): for fname in os.listdir(self.datadir): if fname < self._timestamp: try: os.unlink(join(self.datadir, fname)) except OSError, err: # pragma: no cover if err.errno != errno.ENOENT: raise self.threadpool.run_in_thread(_unlinkold) class DiskReader(object): Read object from storage. :param device_path: path to device (e.g. /srv/node/sdb) :param datadir: path to destination hash :param name: name of the object (e.g. /a/c/o) :param keep_cache_size: if set, buffers not dropped for smaller files :raises DiskFileNotExist: if the data file can't be found :raises DiskFileDeleted: if the object is deleted :raises DiskFileExpired: if the object is expired def __init__(self, device_path, datadir, name, logger=None, disk_chunk_size=65536, keep_cache_size=None, iter_hook=None, threadpool=None): self.device_path = device_path self.datadir = datadir self.name = name self.logger = logger or \ logging.getLogger('swift.obj.diskfile.diskreader') self.keep_cache_size = keep_cache_size self._keep_cache = False self.quarantined_dir = None self._iter_etag = None self._started_at_0 = False self._read_to_eof = False self._suppress_file_closing = False self._meta_file = None self._data_file = None self._find_data_file() self.fp = open(self._data_file, 'rb') self._metadata = self._read_metadata() self._obj_size = None def _find_data_file(self): if not exists(self.datadir): raise DiskFileNotExist() self._data_file = None with open(join(self.datadir, afile)) as mfp: metadata = read_metadata(mfp) metadata['deleted'] = True raise DiskFileDeleted(metadata['X-Timestamp']) if afile.endswith('.meta') and not self._meta_file: self._meta_file = join(self.datadir, afile) if afile.endswith('.data') and not self._data_file: self._data_file = join(self.datadir, afile) if not self._data_file: raise DiskFileNotExist() def _check_collision(self, metadata): """ :raises DiskFileCollision: on md5 collision """ if 'name' in metadata and metadata['name'] != self.name: self.logger.error(_('Client path %(client)s does not match path ' 'stored in object metadata %(meta)s'), {'client': self.name, 'meta': metadata['name']}) raise DiskFileCollision('Client path does not match path stored ' 'in object metadata') def _check_expired(self, metadata): """ :raises DiskFileExpired: if the object is expired """ if ('X-Delete-At' in metadata and int(metadata['X-Delete-At']) <= time.time()): raise DiskFileExpired(metadata['X-Delete-At']) def _check_deleted(self, metadata): """ :raises DiskFileDeleted: if the object is deleted """ if 'deleted' in metadata: raise DiskFileDeleted(metadata['X-Timestamp']) def _check_metadata(self, metadata): """ :raises DiskFileDeleted: if the object is deleted :raises DiskFileExpired: if the object is expired :raises DiskFileCollision: on md5 collision """ self._check_collision(metadata) self._check_deleted(metadata) self._check_expired(metadata) def _read_metadata(self): datafile_metadata = read_metadata(self.fp) if self._meta_file: with open(self._meta_file) as mfp: metadata = read_metadata(mfp) metadata.update(sys_metadata) else: metadata = datafile_metadata self._check_metadata(metadata) return metadata def get_metadata(self): """ Public accessor for consistency with get_obj_size. """ return self._metadata def _read_data_file_size(self): try: file_size = 0 file_size = self.threadpool.run_in_thread( getsize, self._data_file) if 'Content-Length' in self._metadata: metadata_size = int(self._metadata['Content-Length']) if file_size != metadata_size: self.quarantine() raise DiskFileSizeInvalid( 'Content-Length of %s does not match file size ' 'of %s' % (metadata_size, file_size)) return file_size except OSError, err: if err.errno != errno.ENOENT: raise raise DiskFileNotExist('Data File does not exist.') def get_obj_size(self): """ Returns the os.path.getsize for the file. Raises an exception if this file does not match the Content-Length stored in the metadata. Or if self._data_file does not exist. :returns: file size as an int :raises DiskFileSizeInvalid: on file size mismatch. :raises DiskFileNotExist: on file not existing (including deleted) """ if self._obj_size is None: self._obj_size = self._read_data_file_size() return self._obj_size def _drop_cache(self, fd, offset, length): """Method for no-oping buffer cache drop method.""" if not self._keep_cache: drop_buffer_cache(fd, offset, length) file_size = self.get_obj_size() if self.keep_cache_size and file_size < self.keep_cache_size: self._keep_cache = True self._started_at_0 = False self._read_to_eof = False if self.fp.tell() == 0: self._started_at_0 = True self._iter_etag = hashlib.md5() if self._iter_etag: self._iter_etag.update(chunk) self._read_to_eof = True if not self._suppress_file_closing: if not self._suppress_file_closing: self._suppress_file_closing = True self._suppress_file_closing = False if self._data_file and not self.quarantined_dir: quarantine_renamer, self.device_path, self._data_file) def _handle_close_quarantine(self): """Check if file needs to be quarantined""" if self.quarantined_dir: return if self._iter_etag and self._started_at_0 and self._read_to_eof and \ 'ETag' in self._metadata and \ self._iter_etag.hexdigest() != self._metadata.get('ETag'): self.quarantine() def close(self): Close the file. Will handle quarantining file if necessary. """ if self.fp: try: self._handle_close_quarantine() except (Exception, Timeout), e: self.logger.error(_( 'ERROR DiskFile %(data_file)s in ' '%(data_dir)s close failure: %(exc)s : %(stack)s'), {'exc': e, 'stack': ''.join(traceback.format_stack()), 'data_file': self._data_file, 'data_dir': self.datadir}) finally: self.fp.close() self.fp = None def __enter__(self): return self def __exit__(self, t, v, tb): self.close() class DiskFile(object): """ Manage object files on disk. :param path: path to devices on the node :param device: device name :param partition: partition on the device the object lives in :param account: account name for the object :param container: container name for the object :param obj: object name for the object :param disk_chunk_size: size of chunks on file reads :param bytes_per_sync: number of bytes between fdatasync calls :param iter_hook: called when __iter__ returns a chunk :param threadpool: thread pool in which to do blocking operations """ def __init__(self, path, device, partition, account, container, obj, logger, disk_chunk_size=65536, bytes_per_sync=(512 * 1024 * 1024), iter_hook=None, threadpool=None, obj_dir='objects', mount_check=False): if mount_check and not check_mount(path, device): raise DiskFileDeviceUnavailable() self.disk_chunk_size = disk_chunk_size self.bytes_per_sync = bytes_per_sync self.iter_hook = iter_hook self.name = '/' + '/'.join((account, container, obj)) name_hash = hash_path(account, container, obj) self.datadir = join( path, device, storage_directory(obj_dir, partition, name_hash)) self.device_path = join(path, device) self.logger = logger self.threadpool = threadpool or ThreadPool(nthreads=0) self._reader = None def open(self, keep_cache_size=None): """ Read metadata and prepare DiskFile for reading. """ return DiskReader(self.device_path, self.datadir, self.name, logger=self.logger, disk_chunk_size=self.disk_chunk_size, keep_cache_size=keep_cache_size, iter_hook=self.iter_hook, threadpool=self.threadpool) def read_metadata(self, verify_data_file_size=True): with self.open() as dfr: if verify_data_file_size: dfr.get_obj_size() return dfr.get_metadata() @contextmanager def create(self, size=None): """ Context manager to create a file. We create a temporary file first, and then return a DiskWriter object to encapsulate the state. :param size: optional initial size of file to explicitly allocate on disk :raises DiskFileNoSpace: if a size is specified and allocation fails """ with DiskWriter(self.device_path, self.datadir, self.name, size=size) as writer: yield writer # FIXME(clayg): this is handy for tests, but sorta sneaky self._data_file = getattr(writer, '_data_file', None) self._metadata = getattr(writer, '_metadata', None) def update_metadata(self, metadata): """ Update metadata associated with an object. :param metadata: dictionary of metadata to be written """ with self.create() as writer: writer.put_metadata(metadata) def delete(self, req_timestamp): """ Write out tombstone and unlink old files. :param req_timestamp: timestamp of the request to delete object """ with self.create() as writer: writer.put_tombstone(req_timestamp)

commit_message:
Add data rollback for functional tests

Functional tests were modified in order to provide cleaning of db after
tests execution. Some non-major refactoring was made to different
modules. All tests were update.

Change-Id: I1ae3ca6f8679da8fa73df461a701b8703c12b8eb

commit_message:
Update to cleanup command for adapter

Now cleaning of db is available trough command line interface via
ostfctl util. In order to clean db use "ostfctl cleandb --dbpath
db-connection-string". db-connection-string is optional flag and its
default is for ostf database.

Change-Id: I0e6161e5b1a4d892e4f092b7506ac2e08e1bc2f8

commit_message:
improve model validation

- add isset to check "real" attribute and not descriptor
- verify only id is set in shortform
- verify either resource or resourceId value is set, not both.

blueprint improve-validation
related-bug: #1242830

Change-Id: Ie9e3f26c5d30cd36e6013a1f0b77c8fe466cb3f7

deleted_lines: hasattr(self, REPORTERSTEP_KEYNAME_ROLE) and (hasattr(self, REPORTERSTEP_KEYNAME_REPORTER) or hasattr(self, REPORTERSTEP_KEYNAME_REPORTERID))

commit_message:
Ignore H803 from Hacking.

H803 checks for a period in commit messages, something the community
clearly rejected as a sensible check: periods in commit messages
should neither be rejected or required.

The email thread on this issue is here:

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2013-June/010837.html

Change-Id: I754e10ca01b3e6f8c6482e1bcd4c2e2ca8c1cfc9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/56/52656/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Make pbr a build-time only dependency
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-10-29 19:31:18.000000000', 'files': ['requirements.txt', 'swift/__init__.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/0717133197d8929a03ec267d4e3c5b1696f02fb3', 'message': "Make pbr a build-time only dependency

This lets you build swift packages that don't require pbr
to be installed at all. You would need pbr on the machine running
rpmbuild / debuild, but not on the machines that install the packages.

Unfortunately, this does not make swift able to be
installed via pip 0.3.1 on Lucid; you'll need to uninstall the system
python-pip package and install a new pip some other way. Given that
pip < 1.3 doesn't perform SSL certificate validation for pypi (trivial
MITM attack, anyone?), you'd probably want to get a new pip anyway.

Change-Id: Ia50a229c5ae4dd2158beeaa953619b5e8f987c55
"}]
commit_message:
Make pbr a build-time only dependency

This lets you build swift packages that don't require pbr
to be installed at all. You would need pbr on the machine running
rpmbuild / debuild, but not on the machines that install the packages.

Unfortunately, this does not make swift able to be
installed via pip 0.3.1 on Lucid; you'll need to uninstall the system
python-pip package and install a new pip some other way. Given that
pip < 1.3 doesn't perform SSL certificate validation for pypi (trivial
MITM attack, anyone?), you'd probably want to get a new pip anyway.

Change-Id: Ia50a229c5ae4dd2158beeaa953619b5e8f987c55
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/04/54404/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import pkg_resources try: # First, try to get our version out of PKG-INFO. If we're installed, # this'll let us find our version without pulling in pbr. After all, if # we're installed on a system, we're not in a Git-managed source tree, so # pbr doesn't really buy us anything. __version__ = __canonical_version__ = pkg_resources.get_provider( pkg_resources.Requirement.parse('swift')).version except pkg_resources.DistributionNotFound: # No PKG-INFO? We're probably running from a checkout, then. Let pbr do # its thing to figure out a version number. import pbr.version _version_info = pbr.version.VersionInfo('swift') __version__ = _version_info.release_string() __canonical_version__ = _version_info.version_string()
deleted_lines: import pbr.version _version_info = pbr.version.VersionInfo('swift') __version__ = _version_info.release_string() __canonical_version__ = _version_info.version_string()

commit_message:
Fix tests to work with mysql+postgres concurrently

Optimise tests.db.test_migrations and tests.db.test_migration_utils for
concurrency and make opportunistic tests obey walk_style configurations.

Closes-Bug: 1207750

Change-Id: Idb30f144fb67aefc58749897d774103c3c0ec640
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/37/40137/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # We start each walk with a completely blank slate. self._reset_database(key) self._walk_versions(engine, self.snake_walk, self.downgrade) """Base class fort testing migrations and migration utils. This sets up and configures the databases to run tests against. """ # NOTE(jhesketh): It is expected that tests clean up after themselves. # This is necessary for concurrency to allow multiple tests to work on # one database. # The full migration walk tests however do call the old _reset_databases() # to throw away whatever was there so they need to operate on their own # database that we know isn't accessed concurrently. # Hence, BaseWalkMigrationTestCase overwrites the engine list. self.downgrade = False self._load_config() def _load_config(self): self.downgrade = cp.getboolean('walk_style', 'downgrade') # NOTE(jhesketh): We only need to make sure the databases are created # not necessarily clean of tables. self._create_databases() def _create_databases(self): """Create all configured databases as needed.""" for key, engine in self.engines.items(): self._create_database(key) def _create_database(self, key): """Create database if it doesn't exist.""" conn_string = self.test_databases[key] conn_pieces = urlparse.urlparse(conn_string) if conn_string.startswith('mysql'): (user, password, database, host) = \ get_mysql_connection_info(conn_pieces) sql = "create database if not exists %(database)s;" % locals() cmd = ("mysql -u \"%(user)s\" %(password)s -h %(host)s " "-e \"%(sql)s\"") % locals() self.execute_cmd(cmd) elif conn_string.startswith('postgresql'): (user, password, database, host) = \ get_pgsql_connection_info(conn_pieces) os.environ['PGPASSWORD'] = password os.environ['PGUSER'] = user sqlcmd = ("psql -w -U %(user)s -h %(host)s -c" " '%(sql)s' -d template1") sql = ("create database if not exists %(database)s;") % locals() createtable = sqlcmd % locals() self.execute_cmd(createtable) os.unsetenv('PGPASSWORD') os.unsetenv('PGUSER') def _reset_databases(self): """Reset all configured databases.""" for key, engine in self.engines.items(): self._reset_database(key) def _reset_database(self, key): """Reset specific database.""" engine = self.engines[key] conn_string = self.test_databases[key] conn_pieces = urlparse.urlparse(conn_string) engine.dispose() if conn_string.startswith('sqlite'): # We can just delete the SQLite database, which is # the easiest and cleanest solution db_path = conn_pieces.path.strip('/') if os.path.exists(db_path): os.unlink(db_path) # No need to recreate the SQLite DB. SQLite will # create it for us if it's not there... elif conn_string.startswith('mysql'): # We can execute the MySQL client to destroy and re-create # the MYSQL database, which is easier and less error-prone # than using SQLAlchemy to do this via MetaData...trust me. (user, password, database, host) = \ get_mysql_connection_info(conn_pieces) sql = ("drop database if exists %(database)s; " "create database %(database)s;") % locals() cmd = ("mysql -u \"%(user)s\" %(password)s -h %(host)s " "-e \"%(sql)s\"") % locals() self.execute_cmd(cmd) elif conn_string.startswith('postgresql'): self._reset_pg(conn_pieces) class BaseWalkMigrationTestCase(BaseMigrationTestCase): """BaseWalkMigrationTestCase loads in an alternative set of databases for testing against. This is necessary as the default databases can run tests concurrently without interferring with itself. It is expected that databases listed under [migraiton_dbs] in the configuration are only being accessed by one test at a time. Currently only test_walk_versions accesses the databases (and is the only method that calls _reset_database() which is clearly problematic for concurrency). """ def _load_config(self): # Load test databases from the config file. Only do this # once. No need to re-run this on each test... LOG.debug('config_path is %s' % self.CONFIG_FILE_PATH) if os.path.exists(self.CONFIG_FILE_PATH): cp = ConfigParser.RawConfigParser() try: cp.read(self.CONFIG_FILE_PATH) config = cp.options('migration_dbs') for key in config: self.test_databases[key] = cp.get('migration_dbs', key) self.snake_walk = cp.getboolean('walk_style', 'snake_walk') self.downgrade = cp.getboolean('walk_style', 'downgrade') except ConfigParser.ParsingError as e: self.fail("Failed to read test_migrations.conf config " "file. Got error: %s" % e) else: self.fail("Failed to find test_migrations.conf config " "file.") self.engines = {} for key, value in self.test_databases.items(): self.engines[key] = sqlalchemy.create_engine(value) self._create_databases() self._reset_database(database) self._walk_versions(engine, self.snake_walk, self.downgrade) del(self.engines[database]) del(self.test_databases[database]) self._reset_database(database) self._walk_versions(engine, self.snake_walk, self.downgrade) del(self.engines[database]) del(self.test_databases[database])class TestNovaMigrations(BaseWalkMigrationTestCase, CommonTestsMixIn): # Check indexes are gone if engine.name == 'mysql' or engine.name == 'postgresql': data = { # table_name: ((idx_1, (c1, c2,)), (idx2, (c1, c2,)), ...) 'quota_usages': ( ('ix_quota_usages_user_id_deleted', ('user_id', 'deleted')), ), 'reservations': ( ('ix_reservations_user_id_deleted', ('user_id', 'deleted')), ) } meta = sqlalchemy.MetaData() meta.bind = engine for table_name, indexes in data.iteritems(): table = sqlalchemy.Table(table_name, meta, autoload=True) current_indexes = [(i.name, tuple(i.columns.keys())) for i in table.indexes] for index in indexes: self.assertNotIn(index, current_indexes) class TestBaremetalMigrations(BaseWalkMigrationTestCase, CommonTestsMixIn):
deleted_lines: self._walk_versions(engine, self.snake_walk) """Base class fort testing migrations and migration utils.""" # We start each test case with a completely blank slate. self._reset_databases() def tearDown(self): # We destroy the test data store between each test case, # and recreate it, which ensures that we have no side-effects # from the tests self._reset_databases() super(BaseMigrationTestCase, self).tearDown() def _reset_databases(self): for key, engine in self.engines.items(): conn_string = self.test_databases[key] conn_pieces = urlparse.urlparse(conn_string) engine.dispose() if conn_string.startswith('sqlite'): # We can just delete the SQLite database, which is # the easiest and cleanest solution db_path = conn_pieces.path.strip('/') if os.path.exists(db_path): os.unlink(db_path) # No need to recreate the SQLite DB. SQLite will # create it for us if it's not there... elif conn_string.startswith('mysql'): # We can execute the MySQL client to destroy and re-create # the MYSQL database, which is easier and less error-prone # than using SQLAlchemy to do this via MetaData...trust me. (user, password, database, host) = \ get_mysql_connection_info(conn_pieces) sql = ("drop database if exists %(database)s; " "create database %(database)s;") % locals() cmd = ("mysql -u \"%(user)s\" %(password)s -h %(host)s " "-e \"%(sql)s\"") % locals() self.execute_cmd(cmd) elif conn_string.startswith('postgresql'): self._reset_pg(conn_pieces) self._reset_databases() self._walk_versions(engine, False, False) self._reset_databases() self._walk_versions(engine, False, False)class TestNovaMigrations(BaseMigrationTestCase, CommonTestsMixIn):class TestBaremetalMigrations(BaseMigrationTestCase, CommonTestsMixIn):

commit_message:
Claim IPv6 is unsupported if no interface with IPv6 configured

When IPv6 is supported by glibc but no interface
is configured to use ipv6 (because the ipv6 module
is not loaded), skip ipv6 related checks.

Change-Id: I15aaf3d01f0f51bdc0bd29f30728ca2ab8b5c30a

commit_message:
Revert "move single host setup activities to setup_host"

This reverts commit e0df323af67940d6e2951828d3a2289591ab9301.

This is necessary as the changes made in this change are not self test
able and they broke the gate. Revert for now giving us time to write a
proper fix.

Change-Id: Ifda95f159d5ae5818d2674b00824e5adead4b486
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate refs/changes/00/54400/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # HPcloud stopped adding the hostname to /etc/hosts with their # precise images. HOSTNAME=`/bin/hostname` if ! grep $HOSTNAME /etc/hosts >/dev/null then echo "Need to add hostname to /etc/hosts" sudo bash -c 'echo "127.0.1.1 $HOSTNAME" >>/etc/hosts' fi # Hpcloud provides no swap, but does have a virtual disk mounted # at /mnt we can use. It also doesn't have enough space on / for # two devstack installs, so we partition the vdisk: if [ `grep SwapTotal /proc/meminfo | awk '{ print $2; }'` -eq 0 ] && \ [ -b /dev/vdb ]; then sudo umount /dev/vdb sudo parted /dev/vdb --script -- mklabel msdos sudo parted /dev/vdb --script -- mkpart primary linux-swap 0 8192 sudo parted /dev/vdb --script -- mkpart primary ext2 8192 -1 sudo mkswap /dev/vdb1 sudo mkfs.ext4 /dev/vdb2 sudo swapon /dev/vdb1 sudo mount /dev/vdb2 /opt fi echo "Triggered by: https://review.openstack.org/$ZUUL_CHANGE patchset $ZUUL_PATCHSET" echo "Pipeline: $ZUUL_PIPELINE" echo "IP configuration of this host:" ip -f inet addr show setup_host &> $WORKSPACE/logs/devstack-gate-setup-host.txt
deleted_lines: # HPcloud stopped adding the hostname to /etc/hosts with their # precise images. It also doesn't have enough space on / for # two devstack installs, so we partition the vdisk: if [ `grep SwapTotal /proc/meminfo | awk '{ print $2; }'` -eq 0 ] && \ [ -b /dev/vdb ]; then sudo umount /dev/vdb sudo parted /dev/vdb --script -- mklabel msdos sudo parted /dev/vdb --script -- mkpart primary linux-swap 0 8192 sudo parted /dev/vdb --script -- mkpart primary ext2 8192 -1 sudo mkswap /dev/vdb1 sudo mkfs.ext4 /dev/vdb2 sudo swapon /dev/vdb1 sudo mount /dev/vdb2 /opt fi echo "Triggered by: https://review.openstack.org/$ZUUL_CHANGE patchset $ZUUL_PATCHSET" echo "Pipeline: $ZUUL_PIPELINE" echo "IP configuration of this host:" ip -f inet addr show setup_host &> $WORKSPACE/logs/devstack-gate-setup-host.txt

commit_message:
Fix compatibility with latest puppetlabs-concat

concat::setup has been made a private class and can no longer be
included from modules outside concat itself.

concat::setup is already included by the concat define. Removing
its inclusion from puppet-swift classes shouldn't result in breakage
or loss of functionality.

Change-Id: I7566e09bd4e93aec719a495279cf92d8a898057e
Closes-bug: #1245936
(cherry picked from commit 23cc3616cea78b8431181af748a1827add18974f)

commit_message:
Make chef-roles configurable

Change the chef roles hard coded in the recipes and
templates into attributes which can be overriden by
the cookbook end-user.

commit_message:
add metadata-agent network role

...and the accompanied entries in role[os-network] and
infrastructure.yml.

It seems like this was forgotten in the earlier commit,
323843237c10e5a8ebf245bc23ff159f9fe311a5, at least the OVS plugin of
Neutron needs this agent.

Change-Id: I69c0543597624497c9a40e731e355b8f64d5b3fb

commit_message:
move single host setup activities to setup_host

we previously were doing corrections to the host, like the hostname
and vdb setup in setup_workspace instead of setup_host. These really
should only be done once per setup environment, and thus should
not be in setup_workspace.

Change-Id: I53853954f7712a04a205cd3e0b87ece3465e1e0b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate refs/changes/33/54133/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # HPcloud stopped adding the hostname to /etc/hosts with their # precise images. HOSTNAME=`/bin/hostname` if ! grep $HOSTNAME /etc/hosts >/dev/null then echo "Need to add hostname to /etc/hosts" sudo bash -c 'echo "127.0.1.1 $HOSTNAME" >>/etc/hosts' fi # Hpcloud provides no swap, but does have a virtual disk mounted # at /mnt we can use. It also doesn't have enough space on / for # two devstack installs, so we partition the vdisk: if [ `grep SwapTotal /proc/meminfo | awk '{ print $2; }'` -eq 0 ] && \ [ -b /dev/vdb ]; then sudo umount /dev/vdb sudo parted /dev/vdb --script -- mklabel msdos sudo parted /dev/vdb --script -- mkpart primary linux-swap 0 8192 sudo parted /dev/vdb --script -- mkpart primary ext2 8192 -1 sudo mkswap /dev/vdb1 sudo mkfs.ext4 /dev/vdb2 sudo swapon /dev/vdb1 sudo mount /dev/vdb2 /opt fi echo "Triggered by: https://review.openstack.org/$ZUUL_CHANGE patchset $ZUUL_PATCHSET" echo "Pipeline: $ZUUL_PIPELINE" echo "IP configuration of this host:" ip -f inet addr show setup_host &> $WORKSPACE/logs/devstack-gate-setup-host.txt

commit_message:
extract git_checkout into common function

we were basically doing the same thing in three places, make this
a common function so we stop repeating ourselves.

Change-Id: I2bc13a95ce1fbd4fd2645c6e8cc37823b98a6190
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate refs/changes/32/54132/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: function git_checkout { local branch=$1 local reset_branch=$branch if [[ "$branch" != "FETCH_HEAD" ]]; then reset_branch="remotes/origin/$branch" fi git checkout $branch git reset --hard $reset_branch git clean -x -f -d -q } git_checkout FETCH_HEAD git_checkout $BRANCH git_checkout $BRANCH
deleted_lines: git checkout FETCH_HEAD git reset --hard FETCH_HEAD git clean -x -f -d -q git checkout $BRANCH git reset --hard remotes/origin/$BRANCH git clean -x -f -d -q git checkout $BRANCH git reset --hard remotes/origin/$BRANCH git clean -x -f -d -q

commit_message:
Disable nova-compute on libvirt connectivity exceptions

The service will be disabled and re-enabled according to the success
or failure of establishing a connection to the libvirt service.

update_available_resources, periodic task, will probe the connection
even if the service is disabled.

This is in order to avoid migrations or new instances to be scheduled
on a disconnected from libvirt compute node.

Closes-Bug: #1240670
Change-Id: Ib8d67838ceb73c5b1cdc9498c17b335e9e5bb6f3

added_lines: def _update_service_status(self, context, error=None): status = {True: 'Enabled', False: 'Disabled'} service_ref = self.conductor_api.service_get_by_compute_host( context, self.host) enable_host = not bool(error) if service_ref['disabled'] == enable_host: LOG.debug(_('Updating compute service status to: %s'), status[enable_host]) self.driver.set_host_enabled(self.host, error) hypervisor_error = '' try: nodenames = set(self.driver.get_available_nodes()) except Exception as ex: hypervisor_error = ex raise finally: self._update_service_status(context, error=hypervisor_error)
deleted_lines: nodenames = set(self.driver.get_available_nodes())

commit_message:
Sync global requirements with glance

Some tests in master are failing due to variation of behavior of iso8601 package
in versions 0.1.4 vs. v0.1.5 and above. This patch introduces a hack to get the
tests working however, we should soon fix them soon.

Change-Id: I125379f2e400f1b6270e9a2cda30ef2a8e1b3924

commit_message:
Fix bug in Security Group association to Instance

* Refactor of security groups to TaskManager left out an assignment that
  is required for the security_group to be attached to an intance.

fixes bug 1245767

Change-Id: I161d50b2ddb50dbf25eb67e10414425f098b9979

deleted_lines: self._create_secgroup()

commit_message:
Continue reserving H6xx namespace for calling methods

H6xx is reserved for calling methods (see
http://docs.openstack.org/developer/hacking/#calling-methods), so move
the three H6xx tests to more approrate locations.

H601=>H903
H602=>H234 since the issue is that python3 gives an explicit warning
H603=>H235 same reason as H234

Since only H601 has been released, this will have a minor impact

Change-Id: Ie68c9b4421f615b6d76cfb400408c951fc335eeb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/hacking refs/changes/65/54165/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: H234 = hacking.core:hacking_no_assert_equals H235 = hacking.core:hacking_no_assert_underscore H903 = hacking.core:hacking_no_cr
deleted_lines: H601 = hacking.core:hacking_no_cr H602 = hacking.core:hacking_no_assert_equals H603 = hacking.core:hacking_no_assert_underscore

commit_message:
Make InstanceInfoCache load base attributes

The InstanceInfoCache object is pretty bare-bones, previously needing
only the two main attributes. Since the virt/firewall module uses
the deleted flag, we need to load that now.

Related to blueprint compute-manager-objects
Related to blueprint virt-objects

Change-Id: I355a20b402c5581c1582cbe321c63bab58ee4815
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/51/51751/14 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: info_cache.deleted = db_obj['deleted']

commit_message:
Add SecurityGroupRule object

This adds the beginnings of the SecurityGroupRule object, with
linkage back to parent and grantee groups. It is not currently
complete enough to serve as a full implementation, but provides
what we need for virt drivers.

Related to blueprint compute-manager-objects

Change-Id: I4099007c8d4e1c8deaa74cd001cb477a9f164261
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/50/51750/14 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2013 Red Hat, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from nova import db from nova.objects import base from nova.objects import fields from nova.objects import security_group OPTIONAL_ATTRS = ['parent_group', 'grantee_group'] class SecurityGroupRule(base.NovaPersistentObject, base.NovaObject): # Version 1.0: Initial version VERSION = '1.0' fields = { 'id': fields.IntegerField(), 'protocol': fields.StringField(nullable=True), 'from_port': fields.IntegerField(nullable=True), 'to_port': fields.IntegerField(nullable=True), 'cidr': fields.Field(fields.CIDR(), nullable=True), 'parent_group': fields.ObjectField('SecurityGroup', nullable=True), 'grantee_group': fields.ObjectField('SecurityGroup', nullable=True), } @staticmethod def _from_db_object(context, rule, db_rule, expected_attrs=None, expected_sub_attrs=None): if expected_attrs is None: expected_attrs = [] if expected_sub_attrs is None: expected_sub_attrs = {} for field in rule.fields: if field in expected_attrs and db_rule[field]: rule[field] = security_group.SecurityGroup._from_db_object( context, security_group.SecurityGroup(), db_rule[field], expected_attrs=expected_sub_attrs[field]) elif field not in OPTIONAL_ATTRS: rule[field] = db_rule[field] rule._context = context rule.obj_reset_changes() return rule @base.remotable_classmethod def get_by_id(cls, context, rule_id): db_rule = db.security_group_rule_get(context, rule_id) return cls._from_db_object(context, cls(), db_rule) class SecurityGroupRuleList(base.ObjectListBase, base.NovaObject): fields = { 'objects': fields.ListOfObjectsField('SecurityGroupRule'), } @base.remotable_classmethod def get_by_security_group_id(cls, context, secgroup_id): db_rules = db.security_group_rule_get_by_security_group( context, secgroup_id) expected_sub_attrs = { 'grantee_group': 'instances', } return base.obj_make_list(context, cls(), SecurityGroupRule, db_rules, expected_attrs=['grantee_group'], expected_sub_attrs=expected_sub_attrs) @classmethod def get_by_security_group(cls, context, security_group): return cls.get_by_security_group_id(context, security_group.id)

commit_message:
Fix sqlalchemy migrations

This patch only fixes sqlalchemy migrations:
- add InnoDB engine and utf-8 for all tables,
- using of more appropriate exceptions,
- fix logic and syntax errors.

Partially implements bp: db-sync-models-with-migrations

Change-Id: Ifdc4abe06f8cd0e01e13b003ea30d1e402c9e8ba

subject: Add Backup/Restore Checksum Validation
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-10-22 16:50:44.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/trove/commit/bf4fb01f2c10aa49c3ab2b857dc3140b1314fc29', 'message': 'Add Backup/Restore Checksum Validation

Store the swift checksum for swift storage backups. The swift checksum is
the checksum of the concatenated segment checksums.  This is the checksum
that is stored with the DB backup record so we can verify that the checksum
on restore through a swift object HEAD call.

Adds restore from backup checksum validation at API and guestagent level.
* Verify checksum right before downloading swift file
* Verify the current swift backup file checksum matches the original backup
  checksum to prevent loading and restoring a tampered backup file.

Add swift checksum storage unit tests

Implements: blueprint verify-backup-checksum-on-restore
Change-Id: I2844cfb8a8b31f6ea7622f99eff3bea9455161e1
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2013-10-23 14:24:06.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/trove/commit/09569d11cd580b4d23f7474c706216c30352f144', 'message': 'Add Backup/Restore Checksum Validation

Adds restore from backup checksum validation at API and guestagent level.
* Verify checksum right before downloading swift file

Add swift checksum storage unit tests

Implements: blueprint verify-backup-checksum-on-restore
Change-Id: I2844cfb8a8b31f6ea7622f99eff3bea9455161e1
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2013-10-25 16:12:45.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/trove/commit/a09bf4efbcd4cc5ba9439d496a353c6e6b3a63e7', 'message': 'Add Backup/Restore Checksum Validation

Store the swift checksum for swift storage backups. The swift checksum is
the checksum of the concatenated segment checksums.  This is the checksum
that is stored with the DB backup record so we can verify that the checksum
on restore through a swift object HEAD call.

Adds restore from backup checksum validation at API and guestagent level.
* Integrate checksum verification with check object exists at API level.
* Verify checksum right before downloading swift file.
* Verify the current swift backup file checksum matches the original backup
  checksum to prevent loading and restoring a tampered backup file.

Add swift checksum storage unit tests

commit_message:
Add Backup/Restore Checksum Validation

Store the swift checksum for swift storage backups. The swift checksum is
the checksum of the concatenated segment checksums.  This is the checksum
that is stored with the DB backup record so we can verify that the checksum
on restore through a swift object HEAD call.

Adds restore from backup checksum validation at API and guestagent level.
* Integrate checksum verification with check object exists at API level.
* Verify checksum right before downloading swift file.
* Verify the current swift backup file checksum matches the original backup
  checksum to prevent loading and restoring a tampered backup file.

Add swift checksum storage unit tests

Also move backup verification logic outside quotas.

Implements: blueprint verify-backup-checksum-on-restore
Change-Id: I2844cfb8a8b31f6ea7622f99eff3bea9455161e1
