commit_message:
VMware: guest assisted snapshots

This implements volume_snapshot_create which creates a snapshot
of a vmdk volume. In this case prior to the snapshot the volume
needs to be consolidated and detached. Once the snapshot is
complete it will be reattached to the guest.

volume_snapshot_delete is not required as that is implemented
in the Cinder driver.

The create_snapshot API from cinderclient is used to
inform Cinder that it can go ahead and create the snapshot.

This is done using the interface added by the
blueprint qemu-assisted-snapshots.

Change-Id: I94025781aa4e11e0ce97327de5b8319104c8a96d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/02/44602/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova import volume self._volume_api = volume.API() def volume_snapshot_create(self, context, instance, volume_id, create_info): """Snapshots volumes attached to a specified instance.""" driver_type = create_info['driver_volume_type'] LOG.debug(_("Volume snapshot create. Driver type: %s"), driver_type, instance=instance) if driver_type == 'vmdk': data = create_info['data'] mountpoint = data['mountpoint'] self._detach_volume_vmdk(create_info, instance, mountpoint) name = data['name'] description = data['description'] try: self._volume_api.create_snapshot(context, volume_id, name, description) except Exception as e: LOG.warning(_('Voulme snapshow creation failed %s'), e) # Continue - need to attach the volume that was detached self._attach_volume_vmdk(create_info, instance, mountpoint)

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-10-11 04:09:06.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/glance/commit/f46f6a83d0817159b96c26135d0cba060e661b6f', 'message': 'checking number of argument

Currently, "image id" is got by "pop" method without checking number of
argument.
Consequently, some arguments ignored in using multple arguments.

In order to check of size, I replaced "try/except" statement
with "if/else" statement.

Change-Id: I5cff1f9b5fe8f718ca74f1c9f58dba469396dc8f
Closes-Bug: #1236709
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2013-10-15 07:57:19.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/glance/commit/3aed01decb490557781638bf042dcf23d8853070', 'message': 'checking length of argument list in "glance-cache-image" command

Currently, "image id" is got by "pop" method without checking length
of argument list in "queue_image" method(glance/cmd/cache_manage.py)

Consequently, only last element of argument list is used,
other elements is ignored.
 ex)
  glance-cache-image queue-image <image-id1> <image-id2> <image-id3>
  -> <image-id3> is selected and queued.
     <image-id1>/<image-id2> is ignored.

Because "glance-cache-image" command is user command(*),
I think that elements which are ignored should not be existed
and check of length is critical.

In order to check of length, I replaced "try/except" statement with
"if/else" statement.

Also,I modified 2 methods at same point.
 -delete_queued_image
 -delete_cached_image

 * http://docs.openstack.org/developer/glance/cache.html

Change-Id: I5cff1f9b5fe8f718ca74f1c9f58dba469396dc8f
Closes-Bug: #1236709
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2013-10-17 06:54:13.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/glance/commit/2f42afac33744cf4ea87cbe46ce006e76e9eb49c', 'message': 'checking length of argument list in "glance-cache-image" command

     <image-id1>/<image-id2> is ignored.

commit_message:
checking length of argument list in "glance-cache-image" command

Currently, "image id" is got by "pop" method without checking length
of argument list in "queue_image" method(glance/cmd/cache_manage.py)

Consequently, only last element of argument list is used,
other elements are ignored.
 ex)
  glance-cache-image queue-image <image-id1> <image-id2> <image-id3>
  -> <image-id3> is selected and queued.
     <image-id1>/<image-id2> is ignored.

Because "glance-cache-image" command is user command(*),
I think that elements which are ignored should not be existed
and checking of length is essential.

In order to check length, I replaced "try/except" statement with
"if/else" statement.

Also, I modified 2 methods at the same point.
 -delete_queued_image
 -delete_cached_image

 * http://docs.openstack.org/developer/glance/cache.html

Change-Id: I5cff1f9b5fe8f718ca74f1c9f58dba469396dc8f
Closes-Bug: #1236709

commit_message:
feat(logging): format msg when log level met

This is a feature supported by the logging module; just let the
logging function perform the formatting.

Change-Id: I9e349c6bda942474bfe73150b5abb8feb79ed574
Closes-Bug: 1232327

commit_message:
feat: shards mongodb driver + tests

This patch adds shard management capability to the queues mongodb
driver.

The storage API is also correctly split into an control and data
interfaces. The data drivers are loaded by default. The control
drivers are loaded as needed by the transport layer.

Unit tests are also provided to verify that the driver (and future
drivers) work as expected.

Change-Id: Iad034a429a763c9a2ce161f05c928b090ab58944
Partially-implements: blueprint storage-sharding
Partially-Closes: 1241686

added_lines: class ShardsControllerTest(ControllerBaseTest): """Shards Controller base tests. NOTE(flaper87): Implementations of this class should override the tearDown method in order to clean up storage's state. """ controller_base_class = storage.ShardsBase def setUp(self): super(ShardsControllerTest, self).setUp() self.shards_controller = self.driver.shards_controller # Let's create one shard self.shard = str(uuid.uuid1()) self.shards_controller.create(self.shard, 100, 'localhost', {}) def tearDown(self): self.shards_controller.drop_all() super(ShardsControllerTest, self).tearDown() def test_create_succeeds(self): self.shards_controller.create(str(uuid.uuid1()), 100, 'localhost', {}) def test_create_is_silent_on_duplicate_insert(self): name = str(uuid.uuid1()) self.shards_controller.create(name, 100, 'localhost', {}) self.shards_controller.create(name, 100, 'localhost', {}) def _shard_expects(self, shard, xname, xweight, xlocation): self.assertIn('n', shard) self.assertEqual(shard['n'], xname) self.assertIn('w', shard) self.assertEqual(shard['w'], xweight) self.assertIn('l', shard) self.assertEqual(shard['l'], xlocation) def test_get_returns_expected_content(self): res = self.shards_controller.get(self.shard) self._shard_expects(res, self.shard, 100, 'localhost') self.assertNotIn('o', res) def test_detailed_get_returns_expected_content(self): res = self.shards_controller.get(self.shard, detailed=True) self.assertIn('o', res) self.assertEqual(res['o'], {}) def test_get_raises_if_not_found(self): self.assertRaises(storage.exceptions.ShardDoesNotExist, self.shards_controller.get, 'notexists') def test_exists(self): self.assertTrue(self.shards_controller.exists(self.shard)) self.assertFalse(self.shards_controller.exists('notexists')) def test_update_raises_assertion_error_on_bad_fields(self): self.assertRaises(AssertionError, self.shards_controller.update, self.shard) def test_update_works(self): self.shards_controller.update(self.shard, weight=101, location='redis://localhost', options={'a': 1}) res = self.shards_controller.get(self.shard, detailed=True) self._shard_expects(res, self.shard, 101, 'redis://localhost') self.assertEqual(res['o'], {'a': 1}) def test_delete_works(self): self.shards_controller.delete(self.shard) self.assertFalse(self.shards_controller.exists(self.shard)) def test_delete_nonexistent_is_silent(self): self.shards_controller.delete('nonexisting') def test_drop_all_leads_to_empty_listing(self): self.shards_controller.drop_all() cursor = self.shards_controller.list() self.assertRaises(StopIteration, next, cursor) def test_listing_simple(self): # NOTE(cpp-cabrera): base entry interferes with listing results self.shards_controller.delete(self.shard) for i in range(15): self.shards_controller.create(str(i), i, str(i), {}) res = list(self.shards_controller.list()) self.assertEqual(len(res), 10) for i, entry in enumerate(res): self._shard_expects(entry, str(i), i, str(i)) res = list(self.shards_controller.list(limit=5)) self.assertEqual(len(res), 5) res = next(self.shards_controller.list(marker='3')) self._shard_expects(res, '4', 4, '4') res = list(self.shards_controller.list(detailed=True)) self.assertEqual(len(res), 10) for i, entry in enumerate(res): self._shard_expects(entry, str(i), i, str(i)) self.assertIn('o', entry) self.assertEqual(entry['o'], {})

commit_message:
Expose /drivers on the API

The /drivers resource will return a list of drivers supported accross
all the conductors.

Change-Id: I3a86bb8cad2a9a86114c3f19a22835fa3771147e

You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import pecan from pecan import rest from wsme import types as wtypes import wsmeext.pecan as wsme_pecan from ironic.api.controllers.v1 import base from ironic.openstack.common import log LOG = log.getLogger(__name__) class Driver(base.APIBase): """API representation of a driver.""" name = wtypes.text @classmethod def convert(cls, name): driver = Driver() driver.name = name return driver class DriverList(base.APIBase): """API representation of a list of drivers.""" drivers = [Driver] "A list containing drivers objects" @classmethod def convert(cls, drivers): collection = DriverList() collection.drivers = [Driver.convert(driver) for driver in drivers] return collection class DriversController(rest.RestController): """REST controller for Drivers.""" @wsme_pecan.wsexpose(DriverList) def get_all(self): """Retrieve a list of drivers.""" drivers = pecan.request.dbapi.list_active_conductor_drivers(180) return DriverList.convert(drivers)

commit_message:
Add context to TaskManager

Some drivers methods can require context-specific
info. Example: keystone auth enabled, auth_token
required for deploy with use vendor_passthru in API.
Possible usage:
with task_manager.acquire(context, node_id,
                          shared=False) as task:
...
    task.driver.deploy.deploy(task, node_obj)
...

def deploy(self, task, node):
...
    token = task.context.auth_token
    if token:
...

Change-Id: Id51c005499ac4013142f71703a6aa2dca067f1ad

deleted_lines: def acquire(node_ids, shared=False, driver_name=None): t = TaskManager(shared) def __init__(self, shared):

commit_message:
Use string selector values in Fn::Select calls

Heat changed the behavior of handling Fn::Select selector
values and no longer accepts integer values, so we should
use string ones.

ATTENTION: this should only be approved if current Heat behavior
is considered to be correct.

Closes-Bug: #1245863

Change-Id: Ie5c6f766283173e62fe057675279f17baf3dd2f0

commit_message:
Always set model = 'netfront' for xen over libvirt.

This will prevent emulated network driver to be attached to virtual machine.
Emulated network driver is not working for xen over libvirt as tap interface
name is suffixed by xen with '-emu' which makes this interface name too long.

Additionaly security groups will also not work for this interface as openstack
is setting up filters on interface without -emu suffix.

Change-Id: I0907ce148e473edf6b81ea782fac2fa6a1b71a2d
Fixes: bug #1202199
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/77/37477/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # For xen over libvirt we need to always use PV network # drives as emulated ones will not work (xen suffixes them # -emu which makes interface name to long). Additionaly # security groups will not also work for -emu suffixed interfaces. elif CONF.libvirt_type == "xen": model = "netfront"

commit_message:
Check existence of directory 'lost+found'

The command `sudo rmdir $TARGET_ROOT/lost+found` will fail
if `$TARGET_ROOT/lost+found` directory doesn't exist,
e.g. when you use non-default image.

Fixes bug #1245856

Change-Id: I48c8f2f201b29912a726249023ca7d20893cc958
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/11/54311/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if [ -e "$TARGET_ROOT/lost+found" ]; then sudo rmdir $TARGET_ROOT/lost+found fi
deleted_lines: sudo rmdir $TARGET_ROOT/lost+found

commit_message:
Implement /nodes/UUID/vendor_passthru in the API

The RPC and Conductor layers are already done;
this patch adds some exception handling and implements the
RPC bindings inside the API service so that /vendor_passthru
will be possible.

Change-Id: Iba3feae0445a0eb202efc5b9a346fb9931dc4b00
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/61/53761/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: @wsme_pecan.wsexpose(None, unicode, unicode, body=unicode, status_code=202) def _default(self, node_id, method, data): # Only allow POST requests if pecan.request.method.upper() != "POST": raise exception.NotFound raise NotImplementedError()

commit_message:
Introduce GA manager mixin

Code, common for Managers, is extracted to a mixin.
Application and ApplicationStatus instances
accessed by Manager should be contained in Manager
instance rather then being instantiated each time
or retrieved as a singleton.

Change-Id: I35b679735f316467eb7e9f67956c4d1fab1e73e5
Implements: blueprint refactor-ga-for-other-engines-support

listen_ssl is insufficient to enable SSL because it doesn't enable

Change-Id: I42dc29424aee5d8abefeb26b84825daf4afa4ec7

commit_message:
When listen_ssl is true, enable the SSL engine and set a cert/key

listen_ssl is insufficient to enable SSL because it doesn't enable
the SSL engine and doesn't set a certificate and key to use.

Change-Id: I42dc29424aee5d8abefeb26b84825daf4afa4ec7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-horizon refs/changes/99/49799/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: $httpd_cert = '/etc/pki/tls/certs/httpd.crt' $httpd_key = '/etc/pki/tls/private/httpd.key' $httpd_cert = '/etc/ssl/localcerts/apache.crt' $httpd_key = '/etc/ssl/localcerts/apache.key'

commit_message:
python3: use six.text_types for unicode()

Type for representing (Unicode) textual data. This is unicode() in Python 2 and str in Python 3.

Change-Id: I8319287f3294ebf7c1a506cd4f68509d9554a5ef
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/60/52660/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: raise ValueError(six.text_type(e)) except TypeError as e: raise ValueError(six.text_type(e))
deleted_lines: raise ValueError(unicode(e)) except TypeError as e: raise ValueError(unicode(e))

commit_message:
Add werkzeug to global-requirements

We need to use the werkzeug.utils.cached_property decorator in horizon
(https://review.openstack.org/#/c/53859/) and in tuskar-ui
(https://review.openstack.org/#/c/53815/).

Change-Id: I54ff33fb237ca9d96f1cc0c31a8a8b1a92addfd5

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-08-16 17:33:22.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/278d455d55fdc3a54b662d4e566a092248831d39', 'message': "Add block device handling to build_and_run_instance

If we have block device mappings we want to prep them and pass them to
the virt driver spawn method so they can be attached to the instance.
If there's a failure during the instance creation the volumes will get
cleaned up.

A failure to prep the block devices will abort a build because it can't
be built as desired and the failure is not likely to be related to the
compute node itself.

On an instance build failure we make an attempt to clean up the block
devices for the instance.  If that fails we are left in a bad state and
will not attempt to reschedule the instance.

build_and_run_instance method.

Part of bp query-scheduler

commit_message:
Add block device handling to build_and_run_instance

If we have block device mappings we want to prep them and pass them to
the virt driver spawn method so they can be attached to the instance.
If there's a failure during the instance creation the volumes will get
cleaned up.

A failure to prep the block devices will abort a build because it can't
be built as desired and the failure is not likely to be related to the
compute node itself.

On an instance build failure we make an attempt to clean up the block
devices for the instance.  If that fails we are left in a bad state and
will not attempt to reschedule the instance.

This is one part of a series of patches to build up the
build_and_run_instance method.

Part of bp remove-cast-to-schedule-run-instance

Change-Id: I4f9e3fd0b7bb443406645c1d98e673a4d3624b58

commit_message:
python3: fix print statements

Fix print statements while running with python3. This is
due to the fact that the print() has changed between
python2 and python3.

Change-Id: I17f3e008330952ccd5abbe02b7b16c8b893e3b7e
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-neutronclient refs/changes/62/53462/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from __future__ import print_function print(_('Deleted %(resource)s: %(tenant_id)s') % {'tenant_id': tenant_id, 'resource': self.resource}, file=self.app.stdout)
deleted_lines: print >>self.app.stdout, (_('Deleted %(resource)s: %(tenant_id)s') % {'tenant_id': tenant_id, 'resource': self.resource})

subject: python3: use six.text_type for unicode
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-10-23 22:30:07.000000000', 'files': ['neutronclient/tests/unit/test_cli20.py', 'neutronclient/shell.py', 'neutronclient/common/serializer.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-neutronclient/commit/59317949ac0e13c3711caadcb8742611bc6baf98', 'message': 'python3: use six.text_type for unicode

Use six.text_type for representing (Unicode) textual data.
This is unicode() in Python 2 and str in Python 3.

Change-Id: Ie7372dddc5ec09c2f02c0a88ae622128360db47e
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>
'}]
commit_message:
python3: use six.text_type for unicode

Use six.text_type for representing (Unicode) textual data.
This is unicode() in Python 2 and str in Python 3.

Change-Id: Ie7372dddc5ec09c2f02c0a88ae622128360db47e
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-neutronclient refs/changes/67/53467/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import six return six.text_type(obj) result.text = six.text_type(data, 'utf-8') else: result.text = six.text_type(data)
deleted_lines: return unicode(obj) result.text = unicode(data, 'utf-8') else: result.text = unicode(data)

commit_message:
Add InstanceList.get_by_security_group()

This provides a way to get a list of instances that are in a given
security group. This alternative to SecurityGroup.instances is
much simpler and avoids the potential for passing around a
SecurityGroup object with a ton of Instance objects attached.

Related to blueprint compute-manager-objects

Change-Id: Iea282ea3559da00a03121d6eff59125a5fbae0b2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/49/51749/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: OPTIONAL_ATTRS = ['instances'] # Version 1.2: Add instances attribute VERSION = '1.2' 'instances': fields.ObjectField('InstanceList', nullable=True), def _from_db_object(context, secgroup, db_secgroup, expected_attrs=None): if expected_attrs is None: expected_attrs = [] if field in expected_attrs: # NOTE(danms): Avoid circular dependency with instance.py from nova.objects import instance as instance_obj # NOTE(danms): This could only be instances right now secgroup[field] = instance_obj._make_instance_list( context, instance_obj.InstanceList(), db_secgroup['instances'], []) elif field not in OPTIONAL_ATTRS: secgroup[field] = db_secgroup[field] db_secgroup = db.security_group_get(context, secgroup_id, columns_to_join=None) db_secgroup = db.security_group_get_by_name( context, project_id, group_name, columns_to_join=['instances']) return cls._from_db_object(context, cls(), db_secgroup, expected_attrs=['instances'])
deleted_lines: VERSION = '1.1' def _from_db_object(context, secgroup, db_secgroup): secgroup[field] = db_secgroup[field] db_secgroup = db.security_group_get(context, secgroup_id) db_secgroup = db.security_group_get_by_name(context, project_id, group_name) return cls._from_db_object(context, cls(), db_secgroup)

commit_message:
Make security_group_rule_get_by_security_group() honor columns

This makes the above-mentioned method take a columns_to_join
parameter, which lets us control it preloading behavior.

Related to blueprint compute-manager-objects

Change-Id: Ie2404633045c4ebac74225a44cbb609cf4c70887

commit_message:
Replace qpid_host with qpid_hostname

This patch replaces `qpid_host` with `qpid_hostname` in both the
documentation and the config file sample. `qpid_host` has been shipped
as the parameter to specify qpid's hostname, although the correct one is
`qpid_hostname`.

DocImpact
Closes-bug 1242715

Change-Id: I25f2d0e505560e1762f7f059728c33c47a23439e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/31/52931/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Fix remove role assignment adds role using LDAP assignment

When using the LDAP assignment backend, attempting to remove a
role assignment when the role hadn't been used before would
actually add the role assignment and would not return a
404 Not Found like the SQL backend.

This change makes it so that when attempt to remove a role that
wasn't assigned then 404 Not Found is returned.

Closes-Bug: #1242855
Change-Id: I28ccd26cc4bb1a241d0363d0ab52d2c11410e8b3
(cherry picked from commit c6800ca1ac984c879e75826df6694d6199444ea0)
(cherry picked from commit b17e7bec768bd53d3977352486378698a3db3cfa)

commit_message:
Fix remove role assignment adds role using LDAP assignment

When using the LDAP assignment backend, attempting to remove a
role assignment when the role hadn't been used before would
actually add the role assignment and would not return a
404 Not Found like the SQL backend.

This change makes it so that when attempt to remove a role that
wasn't assigned then 404 Not Found is returned.

Closes-Bug: #1242855
Change-Id: I28ccd26cc4bb1a241d0363d0ab52d2c11410e8b3

commit_message:
Optimize the scenario runner

1. Create openstack clients in the ScenarioRunner.run method, i.e. one time
   for all scenario loops (speedup);
2. Get rid of the useless Scenario.class_init() method
3. Move cleanup inside the scenario loop run to enable the cleanup
   implementations to delete the user's resources the scenario was run with;

Blueprint test-engine

Change-Id: I7f8d439baaf4a86539e6cebe7ac83d8fddcd4a47

commit_message:
Use ServerDTO.ssh in devstack engine

blueprint serverdto-ssh

Change-Id: I049f9ba009895fffeddae77e26e903c80314c00d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/81/53581/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from rally import utils @utils.log_task_wrapper(LOG.info, _("Prepare server for devstack")) def prepare_server(self, server): server.ssh.execute_script(script_path) @utils.log_task_wrapper(LOG.info, _("Deploy devstack")) def deploy(self): self.servers = self._vm_provider.create_vms() for server in self.servers: self.prepare_server(server) devstack_server = provider.ServerDTO(server.uuid, server.ip, DEVSTACK_USER, server.key) self.configure_devstack(devstack_server) self.start_devstack(devstack_server) 'url': 'http://%s/' % self.servers[0].ip, 'uri': 'http://%s:5000/v2.0/' % self.servers[0].ip, 'controller_nodes': self.servers[0].ip, 'compute_nodes': self.servers[0].ip, 'controller_node_ssh_user': self.servers[0].user, @utils.log_task_wrapper(LOG.info, _("Configure devstack")) def configure_devstack(self, server): devstack_repo = self._config.get('devstack_repo', DEVSTACK_REPO) server.ssh.execute('git', 'clone', devstack_repo) server.ssh.upload(config_path, "~/devstack/localrc") @utils.log_task_wrapper(LOG.info, _("Start devstack")) def start_devstack(self, server): server.ssh.execute('~/devstack/stack.sh')
deleted_lines: from rally import sshutils def install_devstack(self, vm): devstack_repo = self._config.get('devstack_repo', DEVSTACK_REPO) sshutils.execute_script(vm.user, vm.ip, script_path) sshutils.execute_command(DEVSTACK_USER, vm.ip, ['git', 'clone', devstack_repo]) def deploy(self): self._vms = self._vm_provider.create_vms() for vm in self._vms: self.install_devstack(vm) self.configure_devstack(vm) self.start_devstack(vm) self._vms.append(vm) identity_host = self._vms[0].ip 'url': 'http://%s/' % identity_host, 'uri': 'http://%s:5000/v2.0/' % identity_host, 'controller_nodes': self._vms[0].ip, 'compute_nodes': self._vms[0].ip, 'controller_node_ssh_user': self._vms[0].user, def configure_devstack(self, vm): task_uuid = self.task['uuid'] LOG.info(_('Task %(uuid)s: Patching DevStack for VM %(vm_ip)s...') % {'uuid': task_uuid, 'vm_ip': vm.ip}) sshutils.upload_file(DEVSTACK_USER, vm.ip, config_path, "~/devstack/localrc") LOG.info(_('Task %(uuid)s: DevStack for VM %(vm_ip)s successfully ' 'patched.') % {'uuid': task_uuid, 'vm_ip': vm.ip}) def start_devstack(self, vm): task_uuid = self.task['uuid'] LOG.info(_('Task %(uuid)s: Starting DevStack for VM %(vm_ip)s...') % {'uuid': task_uuid, 'vm_ip': vm.ip}) sshutils.execute_command(DEVSTACK_USER, vm.ip, ['~/devstack/stack.sh']) LOG.info(_('Task %(uuid)s: DevStack for VM %(vm_ip)s successfully ' 'started.') % {'uuid': task_uuid, 'vm_ip': vm.ip})

commit_message:
Make use of oslo.context

Make cinder.context.RequestContext inherit from oslo's RequestContext.
This allows us to reduce copy/paste level and drop some compatibility
shims.

Partial-Bug: #1239925

Change-Id: I0e7887b7ab35bc774aa309b31d910022a5328aa1

commit_message:
Make use of oslo.context

- Pull latest oslo.context (oslo-incubator @ 339cdff)
- Make nova.context.RequestContext inherit from RequestContext from oslo.
  This allows us to save some copy/paste and drop some compatibility
  shims.

Partial-Bug: #1239925

Change-Id: I73c6e82d88ae5c16ce88eb10a638792dcc8880e3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/90/52890/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova.openstack.common import contextclass RequestContext(context.RequestContext): super(RequestContext, self).__init__(auth_token, user_id, project_id, is_admin, None, read_deleted, request_id)
deleted_lines: import uuiddef generate_request_id(): return 'req-' + str(uuid.uuid4()) class RequestContext(object): if not request_id: request_id = generate_request_id() self.request_id = request_id self.auth_token = auth_token # NOTE(sirp): the openstack/common version of RequestContext uses # tenant/user whereas the Nova version uses project_id/user_id. We need # this shim in order to use context-aware code from openstack/common, like # logging, until we make the switch to using openstack/common's version of # RequestContext. @property def tenant(self): return self.project_id @property def user(self): return self.user_id

commit_message:
clean up numeric expressions with byte constants

Replace numeric expressions with constants in nova/virt
to make code more readable.

Implements: blueprint byte-unit-clean

Change-Id: I71aba00ac3c33931082cf0402e4b68764caa0212
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/93/51193/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova.utils import unit data["disk_total"] = ds[2] / unit.Gb data["disk_available"] = ds[3] / unit.Gb data["host_memory_total"] = summary.hardware.memorySize / unit.Mb data["disk_total"] = ds[2] / unit.Gb data["disk_available"] = ds[3] / unit.Gb
deleted_lines: data["disk_total"] = ds[2] / (1024 * 1024 * 1024) data["disk_available"] = ds[3] / (1024 * 1024 * 1024) data["host_memory_total"] = summary.hardware.memorySize / (1024 * 1024) data["disk_total"] = ds[2] / (1024 * 1024 * 1024) data["disk_available"] = ds[3] / (1024 * 1024 * 1024)

commit_message:
Fix required enum's name in migration

Enums must contain name parameter for PostgreSQL and need to be
deleted after dropping table.

Closes-Bug: #1243652
Closes-Bug: #1243213

Change-Id: I01d18ff25572bbe9e6a8b8c6ae27f250ab154734

commit_message:
Add mailmap file

The .mailmap feature is used to coalesce together commits by the same
person in the shortlog, where their name and/or email address was
spelled differently.
http://git-scm.com/docs/git-shortlog

Change-Id: I9260d12fe52b31feae362995641e94969ea6bbbb

commit_message:
Modified configuration group name to lowercase

Most of the OpenStack project makes use of lower case for
configuration group names. But, 'neutron' was having group
names in either cases. Bug states it is fine to have group
name in upper case for [DEFAULT] but needs to be changed
for others. It was noted that [PLUMgridDirector] was having
characters.

Change-Id: I95f2dad6d5ae17f722202f4917b6ef460cd41e15
Closes-Bug: #1176683

deleted_lines: [PLUMgridDirector]

commit_message:
Updated help text for 'subnet-list' command

Added missing text 'sub' for help text displayed for 'subnet-list'
command.

Following was the earlier command:
$ neutron --help
:
  subnet-delete                  Delete a given subnet.
  subnet-list                    List networks that belong to
a given tenant.
  subnet-show                    Show information of a given subnet.
:

Fixed one:
$ neutron --help
:
  subnet-delete                  Delete a given subnet.
  subnet-list                    List subnets that belong to a given
tenant.
  subnet-show                    Show information of a given subnet.
:

Change-Id: I493d5479e203d1ccecd5e0a73d8c9360a651b99a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-neutronclient refs/changes/44/54244/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: """List sub networks that belong to a given tenant."""
deleted_lines: """List networks that belong to a given tenant."""

revisions:

commit_message:
Add required fields validation for node-create

"ironic help node-create" show chassis_id and driver
are REQUIRED, but if we dont pass these, no any error,
so we should enable the required fields validation
on API level

Change-Id: Ia049e3dc59954bd48158e4c4088c98c8143627e5
Fixes: bug 1245294
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/53/54053/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Required fields missing_attr = [attr for attr in ['driver', 'chassis_id'] if not node_dict[attr]] if missing_attr: msg = _("Missing %s attribute(s)") raise wsme.exc.ClientSideError(msg % ', '.join(missing_attr))

commit_message:
Adding volume readonly-mode-update interface to Cinder client

Adding volume readonly-mode-update interface to shell and client object
(v1 and v2) to allow end user update volume read-only access mode flag.

blueprint read-only-volumes

Related-Id: I4c84614d6541d5f7c358abadb957da7b8c3d9c48
Change-Id: I2d587f301a21c0d42b8940465862da25a70ed5a8
Signed-off-by: Zhi Yan Liu <zhiyanl@cn.ibm.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-cinderclient refs/changes/71/45171/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @utils.arg('volume', metavar='<volume>', help='ID of the volume to update.') @utils.arg('flag', metavar='<0|1>', type=int, help='Flag to indicate whether to update volume to ' 'read-only access mode.') @utils.service_type('volume2') def do_readonly_mode_update(cs, args): """Update volume read-only access mode flag.""" volume = _find_volume(cs, args.volume) cs.volumes.update_readonly_flag(volume, args.flag == 1)

commit_message:
Boot from volume in heat autoscaling.

Added BootFromVolume: Boolean option. And size come from the
flavor.

added_lines:
Cannot find suitable emulator for x86_64
Problem When you attempt to create a VM, the error shows the VM is in the BUILD then ERROR state.
Solution On the KVM host run, cat /proc/cpuinfo. Mare sure the vme and svm flags are set. Make sure that virtualization is enabled in the BIOS settings. Hit F9 during a reboot to check the BIOS settings.

commit_message:
Install Guide: Start Neutron Services at Boot

This commit adds `chkconfig` commands to start Neutron services at boot.

Change-Id: I45d26a2484c04d521740cdd8da46441627d94403
Fixes: bug #1243929
(cherry picked from commit a93e2c08f3b52fc5ebe2e47ceda699b5fa7ce032)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/56/54256/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <para>Make sure basic Neturon-related service are set to start at boot time:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>for s in neutron-{dhcp,l3}-agent; do chkconfig $s on; done</userinput></screen> </step> <step> <para>Restart the <acronym>OVS</acronym> plug-in, and make sure it starts on boot:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>service neutron-openvswitch-agent restart</userinput> <prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>chkconfig neutron-openvswitch-agent on</userinput></screen> agent, and set it to start at boot:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>service neutron-openvswitch-agent restart</userinput> <prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>chkconfig neutron-openvswitch-agent on</userinput></screen> <para>Start neutron-server and set it to start at boot:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>service neutron-server start</userinput> <prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>chkconfig neutron-server on</userinput></screen>
deleted_lines: <para>Restart the <acronym>OVS</acronym> plug-in:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>service neutron-openvswitch-agent restart</userinput></screen> agent:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>service neutron-openvswitch-agent restart</userinput></screen> <para>Start neutron-server:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>service neutron-server start</userinput></screen>

commit_message:
Enable extension access_ips for v3 API

This patch enable extension access_ips, remove old 'access_ip_*'
attributes and related unittest from servers core. And remove
old attributes from api samples.

Partially implements bp nova-v3-api

DocImpact

Change-Id: Id4c8bb721550e317e0695d7876e2faa3d6e91a60

commit_message:
Sync lockutils from oslo

d498c42	Fix to properly log when we release a semaphore...
3e3ac0c	Modify lockutils.py due to dispose of eventlet...

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/53/52153/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import threadingimport fixtures This function yields a `threading.Semaphore` instance (if we don't use eventlet.monkey_patch(), else `semaphore.Semaphore`) unless external is sem = _semaphores.get(name, threading.Semaphore()) try: with lock(name, lock_file_prefix, external, lock_path): LOG.debug(_('Got semaphore / lock "%(function)s"'), {'function': f.__name__}) return f(*args, **kwargs) finally: LOG.debug(_('Semaphore / lock released "%(function)s"'), class LockFixture(fixtures.Fixture): """External locking fixture. This fixture is basically an alternative to the synchronized decorator with the external flag so that tearDowns and addCleanups will be included in the lock context for locking between tests. The fixture is recommended to be the first line in a test method, like so:: def test_method(self): self.useFixture(LockFixture) ... or the first line in setUp if all the test methods in the class are required to be serialized. Something like:: class TestCase(testtools.testcase): def setUp(self): self.useFixture(LockFixture) super(TestCase, self).setUp() ... This is because addCleanups are put on a LIFO queue that gets run after the test method exits. (either by completing or raising an exception) """ def __init__(self, name, lock_file_prefix=None): self.mgr = lock(name, lock_file_prefix, True) def setUp(self): super(LockFixture, self).setUp() self.addCleanup(self.mgr.__exit__, None, None, None) self.mgr.__enter__()
deleted_lines: from eventlet import semaphore This function yields a `semaphore.Semaphore` instance unless external is sem = _semaphores.get(name, semaphore.Semaphore()) with lock(name, lock_file_prefix, external, lock_path): LOG.debug(_('Got semaphore / lock "%(function)s"'), return f(*args, **kwargs) LOG.debug(_('Semaphore / lock released "%(function)s"'), {'function': f.__name__})

commit_message:
Install Guide: Small edits on neutron

Add line breaks as needed for screens
Move agent plugin install at the right place for openSUSE, fix description
Fix typo
Use NEUTRON_PASS,  service, controller consistently
Add some FIXMEs to remind us to add openSUSE/Fedora instructions

Change-Id: I3776ff8bf328840c3eae14ee236ebac8243cd959
backport: havana
(cherry picked from commit 0638317285b1819208937a4f01659717f6b4ce6b)

commit_message:
xen tests: replace assertEquals with assertEqual

In Python 2.6, both assertEqual and assertEquals are
convenience aliases to failUnlessEqual.

In Python 3, failUnlessEqual is explicitly deprecated.

This is part of blueprint assertequal

Change-Id: I570ba5096289538d2364b44f2cdc2ac7ac0a527b

commit_message:
Adds remaining Debian notes

This patch adds Debian specific comments for the installation
of Ceilometer, Heat and neutron.

backport: havana

Change-Id: Iff88e1919dce2e3b6e8fb78e79a53d3b5c898c96
(cherry picked from commit 18083a02fa40fa665e0da1f0269bd4b847553364)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/53/54253/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <para>Before you configure individual nodes for Neutron, you must perform the initial setup required for any OpenStack component: creating a user, a service, endpoint(s), and a database. Once you have completed the steps below, follow the subsections of this guide to set up each of your OpenStack nodes for Neutron.</para> <note os="debian"> <title>Note for Debian users</title> <para>As for the rest of OpenStack, you must configure Networking Services through the <filename>debconf</filename> file. You do not need to manually configure the database or create the Keystone endpoint. You can skip the following steps can. If you must reconfigure the Networking Service, run the following command:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>dpkg-reconfigure -plow neutron-common</userinput></screen> <para>Alternatively, edit the configuration files and manually restart the daemons. Remember that if your database server is installed remotely, you must run the following command before you install the Networking Service: <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>apt-get install dbconfig-common && \ dpkg-reconfigure -plow dbconfig-common</userinput></screen></para> </note> into as root using the password you set previously:</para> <literal>id</literal> property for the service that was returned in the previous step. Use it to create the endpoint:</para> <title>Install networking services on a dedicated network node</title> network node. Dedicated network nodes should have the following NICs: the management NIC (called <para>The management network handles communication between nodes. The data network handles communication coming to and from VMs. The external NIC connects the network node (and the controller node, as well, if you so choose) to the outside world, so your VMs can have connectivity to the outside world.</para> automated firewall configuration tool is in place on RHEL. This graphical interface (and a curses-style interface with <literal>-tui</literal> on the end of the name) enables you to configure IP tables as a basic firewall. You should disable it when you work with Neutron unless you are familiar with the various types of network traffic that are important to Neutron. To disable it, simply launch the program and clear the <guilabel>Enabled</guilabel> check box.</para> filtering so that the network node can coordinate traffic for the VMs. Edit the <filename>/etc/sysctl.conf</filename> file, as follows:</para> <para>When dealing with system network-related configurations, you might need to restart the network service to get the configurations to take effect. Do so with the following command:</para> <note os="debian"> <title>Note for Debian users</title> <para>Because this configuration is automated in the Debian packages through debconf, you do not need to manually configure the <literal>[keystone_authtoken]</literal>, the <literal>[database]</literal> , or the RabbitMQ sections of the Neutron configuration files.</para> </note> <literal>[database]</literal> section in the same <para>Now, you can install, and then configure, a networking plug-in. The networking plug-in is what Neutron uses to perform the actual software-defined networking. There are several options for this. Choose one, follow the <link linkend="install-neutron.install-plug-in" >instructions</link> for it in the linked section, and then return here.</para> <para>Now that you've installed and configured a plug-in (you did do that, right?), it is time to configure the remaining parts of Neutron.</para> <para>To perform DHCP on the software-defined networks, Neutron supports several different plug-ins. However, in general, you use the Dnsmasq plug-in. Edit the <para>Restart the rest of Neutron:</para> <para>After you have configured your <link linkend="install-neutron.dedicated-compute-node" >compute</link> and <link linkend="install-neutron.dedicated-controller-node" >controller</link> nodes, <link linkend="install-neutron.configure-networks">configure the base networks</link>.</para> <note os="debian"> <title>Note for Debian users</title> <para>Debian systems do not have specific plug-in packages. Instead, the <literal>neutron-common</literal> package installs all plug-ins by default. Set an option in the <filename>debconf</filename> file to choose a plug-in. The package automatically modifies the <literal>core_plugin</literal> directive to reflect your choice. Depending on the value of the <literal>core_plugin</literal> directive after you set up the <literal>neutron-common</literal> package, the init script of the Neutron daemons automatically chooses which plug-in configuration file to load from the <filename>/etc/neutron/plugins</filename> folder. Also, the OpenStack Networking Service is already configured to be working directly with OVS, so you do not need to modify the <filename>/etc/neutron/neutron.conf</filename> file to work with it (but you might need to edit it if you wish to use another plug-in).</para> <para>However, you must set up the OVS bridges manually, and install the <literal>neutron-openvswitch-agent</literal> as follows.</para> </note> <para>Start Open vSwitch and configure it to start when the system boots:</para> <para>Regardless of which networking technology you decide to use with Open vSwitch, Neutron, there is some common setup that must be done. You must add the technology that you decide to use with Open vSwitch. You must tell L3 agent and DHCP agent you are using <acronym>OVS</acronym>. Edit the <filename>/etc/neutron/dhcp_agent.ini</filename> files, respectively:</para> <para os="rhel;centos">Additionally, if you a using certain kernels with partial support for namespaces (such as some recent versions of RHEL (not RHOS) and CentOS), you must enable veth support, by editing the above files again:</para> <para>Tell the <acronym>OVS</acronym> plug-in how to connect to the database. To do so, edit the networks. Neutron has support for GRE tunneling, VLANs, and VXLANs. Currently, this guide supports GRE tunneling and VLANs.</para> does not require any special configuration from any physical network hardware. However, it is its own type of protocol, and thus is harder to filter, if you are concerned about filtering traffic on the physical network. commit_message:
Adds remaining Debian notes

This patch adds Debian specific comments for the installation
of Ceilometer, Heat and neutron.

backport: havana

Change-Id: Iff88e1919dce2e3b6e8fb78e79a53d3b5c898c96
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/71/54071/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <note os="debian"><title>Note for Debian users</title> <para>As for the rest of OpenStack, the Networking Services is configured through debconf. So you will not need to manually configure the database manually, or create the Keystone endpoint. Therefore, all the below steps can be skipped. If you need to reconfigure the Networking Service, you can use:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>dpkg-reconfigure -plow neutron-common</userinput></screen> <para>or edit the configuration files and manually restart the daemons. Remember that if your database server is installed remotely, before installing the Networking Service, you will need to do: <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>apt-get install dbconfig-common && \ dpkg-reconfigure -plow dbconfig-common</userinput></screen></para></note> <note os="debian"><title>Note for Debian users</title> <para>Since this is automated in the Debian packages through Debconf, you do not need to manually configure the <literal>[keystone_authtoken]</literal>, the <literal>[database]</literal> , or the RabbitMQ sections of the Neutron configuration files.</para></note> <note os="debian"><title>Note for Debian users</title> <para>On Debian systems, there is no specific plugin packages. Instead, all plugins are installed by default with the <literal>neutron-common</literal> package, and a debconf configuration option will let you choose the plugin you want to use. The package will then automatically modify the <literal>core_plugin</literal> directive to reflect your choice. Depending on what the value is in the <literal>core_plugin</literal> directive after setting-up the <literal>neutron-common</literal> package, the init script of the Neutron daemons will automatically choose which plugin configuration file to load from the <filename>/etc/neutron/plugins</filename> folder. Also, the Networking Service of OpenStack is already configured to be working directly with OVS, so you will not need to modify <filename>/etc/neutron/neutron.conf</filename> to work with it (but you may need to edit it if you wish to use another plugin).</para> <para>However, you still need to setup the OVS bridges manually, and install the <literal>neutron-openvswitch-agent</literal> as per below.</para></note>

subject: Move hypervisor sections out of common
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-10-29 07:39:30.000000000', 'files': ['doc/config-reference/compute/section_hypervisor_hyper-v.xml', 'doc/config-reference/compute/section_hypervisor_kvm.xml', 'doc/config-reference/compute/section_hypervisor_vmware.xml', 'doc/config-reference/compute/section_hypervisor_baremetal.xml', 'doc/config-reference/compute/section_hypervisor_lxc.xml', 'doc/config-reference/compute/section_hypervisor_qemu.xml', 'doc/config-reference/compute/section_hypervisor_powervm.xml', 'doc/config-reference/compute/section_compute-hypervisors.xml', 'doc/config-reference/compute/section_hypervisor_docker.xml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals/commit/90c8cc98d90f154f38684968cb8ecf8516865dd7', 'message': 'Move hypervisor sections out of common

The purpose for common is to host files that are used in multiple guides.

These files were only in use in the configuration reference.

In addition, the content and structure of these files was not very
conducive to sharing between guides.

Therefore, this patch simply moves the hypervisor sections from common
 into the compute area of the config-reference.

Should (in the future) some content from these be required in -
 eg Install Guide or Cloud Admin Guide, it is likely best that they are
chopped apart with appropriate sections divided appropriately.

backport: havana

Change-Id: Ie153ccf810de2dccd32cb7b6ee3076fbac365605
(cherry picked from commit dfbc20accc8209127eb32409e36b961aa6682db9)
'}]
commit_message:
Move hypervisor sections out of common

The purpose for common is to host files that are used in multiple guides.

These files were only in use in the configuration reference.

In addition, the content and structure of these files was not very
conducive to sharing between guides.

Therefore, this patch simply moves the hypervisor sections from common
 into the compute area of the config-reference.

Should (in the future) some content from these be required in -
 eg Install Guide or Cloud Admin Guide, it is likely best that they are
chopped apart with appropriate sections divided appropriately.

backport: havana

Change-Id: Ie153ccf810de2dccd32cb7b6ee3076fbac365605
(cherry picked from commit dfbc20accc8209127eb32409e36b961aa6682db9)

commit_message:
Move hypervisor sections out of common

The purpose for common is to host files that are used in multiple guides.

These files were only in use in the configuration reference.

In addition, the content and structure of these files was not very
conducive to sharing between guides.

Therefore, this patch simply moves the hypervisor sections from common
 into the compute area of the config-reference.

Should (in the future) some content from these be required in -
 eg Install Guide or Cloud Admin Guide, it is likely best that they are
chopped apart with appropriate sections divided appropriately.

backport: havana

Change-Id: Ie153ccf810de2dccd32cb7b6ee3076fbac365605

commit_message:
Install Guide: Small edits on neutron

Add line breaks as needed for screens
Move agent plugin install at the right place for openSUSE, fix description
Fix typo
Use NEUTRON_PASS,  service, controller consistently
Add some FIXMEs to remind us to add openSUSE/Fedora instructions

Change-Id: I3776ff8bf328840c3eae14ee236ebac8243cd959
backport: havana

commit_message:
Replace tests.base part5

It is the fifth step to replace using ceilometer.tests.base with
openstack.common.test.
In this patch is changed for using
openstack.common.test and added needed fixtures in
test classes.

Change-Id: Ic7bed465f499f8546b86899f3345001bd16a9193
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/46/47146/12 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import os.path import functools from testtools import testcasefrom ceilometer.openstack.common import test from ceilometer.openstack.common.fixture import config class TestBase(test.BaseTestCase): self.CONF = self.useFixture(config.Config()).conf self.CONF.set_override('connection', str(self.database_connection), group='database') self.conn = storage.get_connection(self.CONF) self.CONF([], project='ceilometer') #Set a default location for the pipeline config file so the # tests work even if ceilometer is not installed globally on # the system. self.CONF.set_override( 'pipeline_cfg_file', self.path_get('etc/ceilometer/pipeline.yaml') ) def path_get(self, project_file=None): root = os.path.abspath(os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), '..', '..', ) ) if project_file: return os.path.join(root, project_file) else: return root def _skip_decorator(func): @functools.wraps(func) def skip_if_not_implemented(*args, **kwargs): try: return func(*args, **kwargs) except NotImplementedError as e: raise testcase.TestSkipped(str(e)) except Exception as e: if 'not implemented' in str(e): raise testcase.TestSkipped(str(e)) raise return skip_if_not_implemented class SkipNotImplementedMeta(type): def __new__(cls, name, bases, local): for attr in local: value = local[attr] if callable(value) and ( attr.startswith('test_') or attr == 'setUp'): local[attr] = _skip_decorator(value) return type.__new__(cls, name, bases, local) class MixinTestsWithBackendScenarios(object): __metaclass__ = SkipNotImplementedMeta
deleted_lines: from oslo.config import cfg from ceilometer.tests import base as test_base class TestBase(test_base.TestCase): cfg.CONF.set_override('connection', str(self.database_connection), group='database') self.conn = storage.get_connection(cfg.CONF)class MixinTestsWithBackendScenarios(object): __metaclass__ = test_base.SkipNotImplementedMeta

commit_message:
Correct update extension point's check_func for v3 server's controller

When loading update extension point, it should check the extension has
'server_update' function. But current code check with wrong function
name 'server_resize'. And this patch adds testcase for servers extension
point.

Change-Id: I2bee7ff306b3337d24047e471fac9485fec9a6f7
Closes-bug: #1240351

commit_message:
Adding Read-Only volume attaching support to Cinder client

Adding mode argument to volume manager attach function.
Allow Nova using read-write or read-only mode to attach a volume to an
instance.

blueprint read-only-volumes

Change-Id: Ib20c7802304d83f4aafef522171ebd47f672d883
Signed-off-by: Zhi Yan Liu <zhiyanl@cn.ibm.com>

commit_message:
Improve the way of parsing ssh result

Function ssh_read use a loop to wait for complete ssh response from
storage system. But if the ssh connection reaches its limit number,
ssh will get a undefined string and the function will get into a
infinite loop. So we add this case into the loop and limit the max
number of ssh connections to be two. in addition, improve the way of
parsing ssh result to make it work in paramiko 2.7.4.

Those changes were merged into the master branch already:
Ia8761081dff998884f45312355b62aa27ab5417c

Closes-bug: #1224499
Change-Id: I2899c946172394bef9aff87c5432b8f9aa44f71a

Please check ' 'system status.') LOG.error(msg) raise exception.CinderException(msg) elif (re.search(user + ':/>' + cmd, result) and result.endswith(user + ':/>')): volume_size = '100M' else: volume_size = '%sG' % volume['size'] self._create_volume(volume_name, volume_size) self.ssh_pool = SSHConn(ip0, 22, 30, user, pwd, max_size=2) newname = VOL_AND_SNAP_NAME_PREFIX + str(hash(name))

commit_message:
Use "python -m coverage" rather than use "coverage" explicitly

When coverage module is installed using a package from Debian/Ubuntu,
the command name is "python-coverage". By using "python -m coverage"
the coverage module is detected in both cases.

Change-Id: I30cdbbf8bd9a448dc43c3a2abe667ec7803002f3
Closes-Bug: #1241332

commit_message:
Add simple script for clean db

Change-Id: Ied0687e4f1bcaa2dc34eb04a9e5db50b67a6be60
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/30/50530/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova.db.sqlalchemy import model_query from nova.db.sqlalchemy import require_admin_context from nova.openstack.common.db.sqlalchemy import session as db_session class DB_cleaner(object): def __init__(self, models): """ :param models: Module with sqlalchemy models. """ self.models = models self.releationship_tree = dict() self.roots = set() self.tables = dict() def _create_tree_from_module(): """ Just another ugly implementation of db releationship tree. """ for module in dir(self.models): obj = getattr(self.models, module) if '__tablename__' in dir(obj): ref = obj.__tablename__ self.tables[ref] = obj for prop in dir(obj): try: foreign_keys_set = getattr(obj,prop).\ property.columns[0].foreign_keys for i in foreign_keys_set: key, val = i.target_fullname.split('.') if key in self.releationship_tree: if val in self.releationship_tree[key]: if ref not in self.releationship_tree[key][val]: self.releationship_tree[key][val][ref] = prop else: self.releationship_tree[key][val] = {ref:prop} else: self.releationship_tree[key] = {val:{ref:prop}} except: pass #select roots self.roots = self.releationship_tree.keys() for node in self.releationship_tree: for fk in self.releationship_tree[node]: for child in self.releationship_tree[node][fk]: if child in self.roots: self.roots.remove(child) def _purge_node_with_children(self, node, session, ctxt): parent_table = self.tables[node] if node in self.releationship_tree: for fk in self.releationship_tree[node]: for child in self.releationship_tree[node][fk]: deleted_rows = model_query(ctxt, parent_table, session=session).\ filter(parent_table.deleted != 0).all() child_table = self.tables[child] child_col = getattr(child_table, self.releationship_tree[node][fk][child]) for row in deleted_rows: parent_col = getattr(row, fk) model_query(ctxt, child_table, session=session).\ filter(child_col == parent_col).\ soft_delete() self._purge_node_with_children(child, session, ctxt) m = model_query(ctxt, parent_table, session=session).\ filter(parent_table.deleted != 0) m.delete(synchronize_session=False) @require_admin_context def purge_deleted_rows(self, context): _create_tree_from_module() context.read_deleted = "yes" session = get_session() with session.begin(): for node in _roots: Node = self.tables[node] self._purge_node_with_children(node, session, context)

commit_message:
Added some options to openapproved

* --debug, to set the logging level to debug
* --server, to specify a custom server
* --projects-dir, to specify a custom directory to fetch the projects
  from
* Added the detection for the approved status for gerrit 2.6.1

Change-Id: I2f649690b698b6fbf18f5fdad6fa49676b0d2ef9
Signed-off-by: David Caro <dcaroest@redhat.com>

commit_message:
System Tests for HA Murano and Savanna

Change-Id: Ia7f6687f0dcfbc2bbecd0c14675edd8af2167d1b

added_lines: @snapshot_errors @logwrap @fetch_logs @attr(releases=['centos', "ubuntu"], test_thread='thread_3') def test_ha_murano_savanna(self): cluster_id = self.prepare_environment( commit_message:
Added some options to reviews_for_bugs

* --debug, to set the logging level to debug
* --server, to specify a custom server
* --projects-dir, to specify a custom directory to fetch the projects
  from

Change-Id: I9c5ee44a0f5d757c4e3e6ecd5952b19d3a10d87a
Signed-off-by: David Caro <dcaroest@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Added some options to reviewers

* --debug, to set the logging level to debug
* --server, to specify a custom server
* --projects-dir, to specify a custom directory to fetch the projects
  from
* Added proper detection of code review state for gerrit 2.6.1

Change-Id: Ice0ee5f5572337c6724d584368885dd20e712ff0
Signed-off-by: David Caro <dcaroest@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Add next link in Meter/Sample/Resource/Alarm

The next link is used for pagination, it will return the next
set of objects when the object is the last item of previous page.
It is part of bp/paginate-db-search.

Implements blueprint paginate-db-search

Change-Id: Ib7bf115a8bccdfda23eb4f6081adcdd62d9c79a1

subject: Clean up logical volume on resize/migrate
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-10-20 08:07:06.000000000', 'files': ['nova/compute/manager.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/bbaceb4b2de3934fe79e1557924040ed77a6dfee', 'message': 'Clean up logical volume on resize/migrate

When resize/migrate VM, the logical volume on source host was not
deleted, this will cause some garbage logical volume on source host
if resize/migrate to different host.

In addition, if an instance is resized/migrated to a hypervisor with
a previous old logical volume (with that same instance disk ID) it
will simply re-use the existing volume and not upgrade/downgrade the
image size.

The fix was destroy the old logical volume when resize instance,
thus when resize finished, nova compute will try to re-create the
logical volume image again based on new flavor.

Change-Id: Ie967127c7e2611f42d6ed41143c0059767baccc1
Closes-Bug: #1241866
'}]
commit_message:
Clean up logical volume on resize/migrate

When resize/migrate VM, the logical volume on source host was not
deleted, this will cause some garbage logical volume on source host
if resize/migrate to different host.

In addition, if an instance is resized/migrated to a hypervisor with
a previous old logical volume (with that same instance disk ID) it
will simply re-use the existing volume and not upgrade/downgrade the
image size.

The fix was destroy the old logical volume when resize instance,
thus when resize finished, nova compute will try to re-create the
logical volume image again based on new flavor.

Change-Id: Ie967127c7e2611f42d6ed41143c0059767baccc1
Closes-Bug: #1241866
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/11/52811/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add pagination query support for get_samples

Merge the original parameter 'limit' into pagination class.
Provide pagination query support for mongodb and sqlalchemy.
For db2, it supports limit query with given sort instructions.
For hbase, it still only support limit query.
It is part of bp/paginate-db-search.

Implements blueprint paginate-db-search

Change-Id: I43be22166baa42fcfcb76aa480f50b1dfbc1c794

commit_message:
Add support for testing VMware

The basic building blocks for testing VMware are put into place. To
support testing Openstack, the following changes are made:

- vmware test package: All vmware tests will placed in the
  "tempest.vmware.*" package. Packages and tests will follow similar
  naming conventions and hierarchies as laid out by the currently
  existing tests.

- vmware configuration section: A new configuration section, [vmware],
  will be added to tempest.conf. This section will provide options
  to set whether vmware tests should be run at all or not as well as
  control behavior in vmware-specific tests.

- vmware base test case class: All vmware tests will inherit from a
  base test case class that will provide API access to a vmware
  environment under test.

- vsphere api modules: The libraries used to communicate with vmware
  environments will be placed in the "tempest.vmware" package. The
  libraries are similar to those used in nova and cinder to talk with
  vmware hosts or vcenters.

- vmware test: A first test is created to demonstrate what a vmware
  test will look like. This test is a simple one that verifies that
  a server is spawned and exists on a vCenter

Change-Id: I73c25bb1b1083469e3b19f31737feef62aa2279a

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from tempest.vmware import vim_util def get_vm_ref_from_name(session, vm_name): """Get reference to the VM with the name specified.""" vms = session.invoke_api(vim_util, "get_objects", session.vim, "VirtualMachine", ["name"]) return _get_object_from_results(session, vms, vm_name, _get_object_for_value) def _get_token(results): """Get the token from the property results.""" return getattr(results, 'token', None) def _get_object_for_value(results, value): for object in results: if object.propSet[0].val == value: return object.obj def _get_object_from_results(session, results, value, func): while results: token = _get_token(results) object = func(results, value) if object: if token: session.invoke_api(vim_util, "cancel_retrieve", session.vim, token) return object if token: results = session.invoke_api(vim_util, "continue_to_get_objects", session.vim, token) else: return None

commit_message:
support bulk upload in swift and swiftclient

Change-Id: I0d8845abea15d4a28696954b94e027687475cc43
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-swiftclient refs/changes/40/52640/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines:
def bulk_upload(url, token, archive, format, container=None, chunk_size=None, headers=None, http_conn=None, proxy=None,): """Support for Bulk Operations middleware, extract-archive feature. :param url: storage URL :param archive: file like object that will .read() the archive :param format: accepted formats are tar, tar.gz, and tar.bz2 :param token: auth token; if None, no token will be sent :param container: container name that the object is in; if None, the container name will be the directory in the archive's file listing. :param chunk_size: chunk size of data to write; it defaults to 65536; :param headers: additional headers to include in the request, if any :param http_conn: HTTP connection object (If None, it will create the conn object) :param proxy: proxy to connect through, if any; None by default; str of the format 'http://127.0.0.1:8888' to set one :returns: response body, which should be parsed for 'Number Files Created' and/or 'Errors' according to the format specified by the 'Accept' header (default json) :raises ClientException: HTTP PUT request failed :raises ClientException: Unsupported format """ if format == 'tar': content_type = 'application/x-tar' elif format in ['tar.gz', 'tar.bz2']: content_type = 'application/x-gtar' else: raise ClientException( '%s is not a supported archive format. ' % format + 'Supported types: tar, tar.gz, tar.bz2') # TODO: add support for middleware discovery if http_conn: parsed, conn = http_conn else: parsed, conn = http_connection(url, proxy=proxy) path = parsed.path if container: path = '%s/%s' % (path.rstrip('/'), quote(container)) path += '?extract-archive=%s' % format if headers: headers = dict(headers) else: headers = {} if token: headers['X-Auth-Token'] = token headers['Content-Type'] = content_type if chunk_size is None: chunk_size = 65536 conn.putrequest('PUT', path) for header, value in headers.iteritems(): conn.putheader(header, value) conn.putheader('Transfer-Encoding', 'chunked') conn.endheaders() chunk = archive.read(chunk_size) while chunk: conn.send('%x
%s
' % (len(chunk), chunk)) chunk = archive.read(chunk_size) conn.send('0

') resp = conn.getresponse() body = resp.read() http_log(('%s%s' % (url.replace(parsed.path, ''), path), 'PUT',), {'headers': headers}, resp, body) if resp.status < 200 or resp.status >= 300: raise ClientException('Object PUT failed', http_scheme=parsed.scheme, http_host=conn.host, http_port=conn.port, http_path=path, http_status=resp.status, http_reason=resp.reason, http_response_content=body) return body def bulk_upload(self, archive, format, container=None, chunk_size=None, headers=None): """Wrapper for :func:`bulk_upload`""" reset_func = lambda *a, **k: archive.seek(archive.tell()) return self._retry(reset_func, bulk_upload, archive, format, container=container, chunk_size=chunk_size, headers=headers)

commit_message:
ec2 keypairs management from tokens

blueprint ec2-keypairs-from-tokens

This patch allows a trustee to generate an EC2 keypair by
authenticating with a token issued from a trust. When the
keypair is used to authenticate against keystone, the trust
token is returned, effectively giving the same roles
delegations as defined in the trust.

Changes:

* 'token_id' and 'trustee_id' added to the ec2 backend
* identity checks and listing take trustees/tokens into account
* new API call 'create_credential_from_token'
* API call tests (creation, list and delete as trustor)

Change-Id: Ib45771cfb427e6cc686a9d047f82100398f1a646
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/44/40444/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: token_id = sql.Column(sql.String(64), nullable=True) trustee_id = sql.Column(sql.String(64), nullable=True) trustor_refs = query.filter_by(user_id=user_id) trustee_refs = query.filter_by(trustee_id=user_id) credential_refs = trustor_refs.union(trustee_refs)
deleted_lines: credential_refs = query.filter_by(user_id=user_id)

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack-attic/identity-api refs/changes/41/37141/22 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: OpenStack Identity API v3 OS-ROLES Extension ============================================ Provide an ability to associate a role definition with service_id, this extension address following issues. 1. System wide role name uniqueness constraint, now roles will be unique per service. 1. Filtering support for auth_token clients, clients can filter roles based on service_id. API --- The following APIs are supported by this extension: #### Create role: `POST /OS-ROLES/roles` Request: { "name": "", "service_id": "--id--", } Response: Status: 201 Created { "id": "--role-id--", "links": { "self": "http://identity:35357/v3/OS-ROLES/roles/--role-id--" }, "name": "a role name", "service_id": "--service_id--" } #### List roles: `GET /OS-ROLES/roles` query_string: page (optional) query_string: per_page (optional, default 30) query filter for "name" (optional) query filter for "service_id" (optional) Response: Status: 200 OK [ { "id": "--role-id--", "links": { "self": "http://identity:35357/v3/OS-ROLES/roles/--role-id--" }, "name": "a role name" "service_id": "--service_id--" }, { "id": "--role-id--", "links": { "self": "http://identity:35357/v3/OS-ROLES/roles/--role-id--" }, "name": "a role name" "service_id": "--service_id--" } ] #### Get role: `GET /OS-ROLES/roles/{role_id}` Response: Status: 200 OK { "id": "--role-id--", "links": { "self": "http://identity:35357/v3/OS-ROLES/roles/--roles-id--" }, "name": "a role name" "service_id": "--service_id--" } #### Update role: `PATCH /OS-ROLES/roles/{role_id}` Response: Status: 200 OK { "id": "--role-id--", "links": { "self": "http://identity:35357/v3/OS-ROLES/roles/--roles-id--" }, "name": "a role name" "service_id": "--service_id--" } #### Delete role: `DELETE /OS-ROLES/roles/{role_id}` Response: Status: 204 No Content ##### Authentication responses A token scoped to a `project` will also have a service `catalog`, along with the user's roles applicable to the `project`. Example response: Headers: X-Subject-Token X-Subject-Token: e80b74 { "token": { "catalog": "FIXME(dolph): need an example here", "expires_at": "2013-02-27T18:30:59.999999Z", "issued_at": "2013-02-27T16:30:59.999999Z", "methods": [ "password" ], "project": { "domain": { "id": "1789d1", "links": { "self": "http://identity:35357/v3/domains/1789d1" }, "name": "example.com" }, "id": "263fd9", "links": { "self": "http://identity:35357/v3/projects/263fd9" }, "name": "project-x" }, "roles": [ { "id": "76e72a", "links": { "self": "http://identity:35357/v3/roles/76e72a" }, "name": "admin", "OS-ROLES:service_id": "--service_id--" }, { "id": "f4f392", "links": { "self": "http://identity:35357/v3/roles/f4f392" }, "name": "member", "OS-ROLES:service_id": "--service_id--" } ], "user": { "domain": { "id": "1789d1", "links": { "self": "http://identity:35357/v3/domains/1789d1" }, "name": "example.com" }, "id": "0ca8f6", "links": { "self": "http://identity:35357/v3/users/0ca8f6" }, "name": "Joe" } } } A token scoped to a `domain` will also have a service `catalog` along with the user's roles applicable to the `domain`. Example response: Headers: X-Subject-Token X-Subject-Token: e80b74 { "token": { "catalog": "FIXME(dolph): need an example here", "expires_at": "2013-02-27T18:30:59.999999Z", "issued_at": "2013-02-27T16:30:59.999999Z", "methods": [ "password" ], "domain": { "id": "1789d1", "links": { "self": "http://identity:35357/v3/domains/1789d1" }, "name": "example.com" }, "roles": [ { "id": "76e72a", "links": { "self": "http://identity:35357/v3/roles/76e72a" }, "name": "admin", "OS-ROLES:service_id": "--service_id--" }, { "id": "f4f392", "links": { "self": "http://identity:35357/v3/roles/f4f392" }, "name": "member", "OS-ROLES:service_id": "--service_id--" } ], "user": { "domain": { "id": "1789d1", "links": { "self": "http://identity:35357/v3/domains/1789d1" }, "name": "example.com" }, "id": "0ca8f6", "links": { "self": "http://identity:35357/v3/users/0ca8f6" }, "name": "Joe" } } }

added_lines: # vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4 # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import uuid from tempest.api.volume import base from tempest.common.utils.data_utils import rand_name from tempest.openstack.common import log as logging from tempest.test import attr from tempest import exceptions LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class VolumesSnapshotNegativeTest(base.BaseVolumeTest): _interface = "json" @classmethod def setUpClass(cls): super(VolumesSnapshotNegativeTest, cls).setUpClass() @classmethod def tearDownClass(cls): super(VolumesSnapshotNegativeTest, cls).tearDownClass() @attr(type='gate') def test_create_snapshot_with_invalid_volume_id(self): # Create a snapshot with invalid volume id s_name = rand_name('snap') self.assertRaises(exceptions.NotFound, self.snapshots_client.create_snapshot, '#$%%&^&^', display_name=s_name) @attr(type='gate') def test_create_snapshot_with_nonexistent_volume_id(self): # Create a snapshot with nonexistent volume id s_name = rand_name('snap') self.assertRaises(exceptions.NotFound, self.snapshots_client.create_snapshot, str(uuid.uuid4()), display_name=s_name) @attr(type='gate') def test_create_snapshot_without_passing_volume_id(self): # Create a snapshot without passing volume id s_name = rand_name('snap') self.assertRaises(exceptions.NotFound, self.snapshots_client.create_snapshot, '', display_name=s_name) class VolumesSnapshotNegativeTestXML(VolumesSnapshotNegativeTest): _interface = "xml"
